[[File:Somali Piracy Map.png|right|thumb|245px|General area of the [[Indian Ocean]], [[Gulf of Aden]] and [[Socotra Passage]] where pirates operate]]{{GeoGroupTemplate}} Piracy off the [[African horn]] has been a threat to [[Ship transport|international shipping]] since the [[War in Somalia (2006–2009)|second phase]] of the [[Somali Civil War]] in the early 21st century.{{cite news|author=Sanayo|title= Piracy in Somali Waters: Rising attacks impede delivery of humanitarian assistance|work=[[UN Chronicle]]|publisher=[[United Nations]] Department of Public Information, Outreach, Division}} Since 2005, many international organizations have expressed concern over the rise in acts of [[piracy]].{{cite web |url=http://www.imo.org/mediacentre/secretarygeneral/speechesbythesecretarygeneral/pages/piracyactionplanlaunch.aspx |title=Piracy: orchestrating the response |publisher=[[International Maritime Organization]]}}{{cite web |url=http://www.wfp.org/news/news-release/hijackings-cut-aid-access-south-somalia-lives-risk |title=Hijackings cut aid access to south Somalia, lives at risk |publisher=[[World Food Programme]]}} Piracy impeded the delivery of shipments and increased shipping expenses, costing an estimated $6.6 to $6.9 billion a year in global trade according to Oceans Beyond Piracy (OBP).{{cite web|url=http://oceansbeyondpiracy.org/sites/default/files/attachments/View%20Full%20Report_3.pdf|title=The Economic Cost of Somali Piracy 2011|first=Bowden|last=Anna|publisher=Oceans Beyond Piracy}} According to the [[German Institute for Economic Research]] (DIW), a veritable industry of profiteers also arose around the piracy. [[Insurance]] companies significantly increased their profits from the pirate attacks as insurance companies hiked premium rates in response.{{cite web|url=http://www.german-foreign-policy.com/en/fulltext/57866 |title=The Advantage of Piracy |publisher=German-foreign-policy.com |accessdate=17 December 2011}} [[Combined Task Force 150]], a multinational coalition task force, took on the role of fighting the piracy by establishing a [[Maritime Security Patrol Area]] (MSPA) within the [[Gulf of Aden]] and [[Socotra Passage]].{{cite web|title=Combined Task Force 150 Thwarts Criminal Activities|author=Commander, Combined Maritime Forces Public Affairs|publisher=US Africa Command|url=http://www.africom.mil/getArticle.asp?art=2137|date=29 September 2008|accessdate=17 November 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206083436/http://www.africom.mil/getArticle.asp?art=2137|archivedate=6 December 2008|df=}} According to the International Maritime Bureau, pirate attacks had by October 2012 dropped to a six-year low, with only one ship attacked in the third quarter compared to thirty-six during the same period in 2011.{{cite news|last=Alaric Nightingale|first=Michelle Wiese Bockmann|title=Somalia Piracy Falls to Six-Year Low as Guards Defend Ships|url=http://www.businessweek.com/news/2012-10-22/somalia-piracy-attacks-plunge-as-navies-secure-trade-route|accessdate=25 October 2012|newspaper=Bloomberg News|date=22 October 2012}} By December 2013, the US [[Office of Naval Intelligence]] reported that only 9 vessels had been attacked during the year by pirates, with zero successful hijackings.{{cite news|last=Yanofsky|first=David|title=Somali piracy was reduced to zero this year|url=http://qz.com/161704/somali-piracy-was-reduced-to-zero-this-year/|accessdate=14 January 2014|newspaper=Quartz|date=27 December 2013}} [[Control Risks Group|Control Risks]] attributed this 90% decline in pirate activity from the corresponding period in 2012 to the adoption of better management practices by vessel owners and crews, armed private security on board ships, a significant naval presence, and the development of onshore security forces.{{cite news|title=Somali piracy is down 90 per cent from last year|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/piracy-somalia-down-on-last-year-1219326-Dec2013/|accessdate=14 January 2014|newspaper=The Journal|date=15 December 2013}} ==List of ships captured or attacked off the Somali coast== For more details see: * ECOTERRA Intl. Somali Marine & Coastal Monitor - SMCM updates at: [https://web.archive.org/web/20091219232949/http://www.australia.to/index.php?option=com_content&view=category&id=136&Itemid=229] ===2005=== {{Hijacked ship head}} {{Hijacked ship |image= |flag=Hong Kong |owner=Hong Kong |name={{MV|Feisty Gas}} |class=[[LPG carrier]] |crew=120 |cargo=''unknown'' |status=Released
after ransom |ransom=[[United States dollar|US$]]315,000 |cdate=2005-04-10 |rdate=unknown |info=MV ''Feisty Gas'', a liquefied petroleum gas tanker, was seized by Somali pirates. A Hong Kong-based company that owns the vessel reportedly paid $315,000 to a representative of the Somali pirates in Mombasa, Kenya, according to a recent UN report.{{cite news|url=http://www.news24.com/News24/Africa/News/0,6119,2-11-1447_1821590,00.html|title=Pirates: Somalia needs help|date=2005-10-22|accessdate=2008-11-30|publisher=News 24 (South Africa)|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080930222907/http://www.news24.com/News24/Africa/News/0,6119,2-11-1447_1821590,00.html|archivedate=2008-09-30|df=}} }} {{Hijacked ship |image= |flag=Kenya |owner=Kenya |name={{MV|Semlow}} |class=Freighter |crew=10 |cargo=''unknown'' |status=Released |ransom=[[United States dollar|US$]]50,000 |cdate=2005-06-27 |rdate=2005-10-03 |info=MV ''Semlow'', carrying UN food supplies for tsunami victims, was seized by pirates en route from [[Mombasa]], [[Kenya]] to [[Bosasso]], [[Somalia]]. They held the ship for 100 days until a Somali business man convinced them to leave without payment.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/4636695.stm|title=Pirates hijack tsunami aid ship|date=30 June 2005|accessdate=8 February 2011|publisher=BBC News}} }} {{Hijacked ship |image= |flag=Liberia |owner=Ukraine |name={{MV|Panagia}} |class=[[bulk carrier]] |crew=22 all ukrainian |cargo=''coal'' |status=Released
after ransom |ransom=[[United States dollar|US$]]700,000 |cdate=2005-10-18 |rdate=2005-11-25 |info=MV ''Panagia'', a 22b,046 GRT [[bulk carrier]] with [[coal]] from [[South Africa]] to [[Turkey]], was seized by Somali pirates on {{convert|90|nmi|km}} off the east coast. A Ukrainian-based company that owns the vessel reportedly paid $700,000 to a representative of the Somali pirates in [[Mombasa]], [[Kenya]].{{Citation needed|date=July 2009}} }} {{Hijacked ship |image=[[Image:SeabournSpirit crop gobeirne.jpg|100px|Seabourn Spirit]] |flag=Bahamas |owner=United States |name={{MV|Seabourn Spirit}} |class=[[cruise ship]] |crew=210 |cargo=Passengers |status=Capture failed |ransom=''none'' |cdate=2005-11-05 |rdate=c |info={{ship||Seabourn Spirit}}, a luxury cruise ship carrying 210 crew members and passengers, was attacked by pirates off the coast of Somalia.{{cite news |first=Matt |last=Cherry |author2=Moyer, Amanda |title=Cruise liner outruns armed pirate boats |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2005/WORLD/africa/11/05/somalia.pirates/index.html |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=2005-11-06 |accessdate=2008-04-22}} Riding in two small speedboats, the pirates fired at the ship with [[machine guns]] and [[rocket-propelled grenade]]s, but the crew drove them off with a water hose and a [[long range acoustic device]].{{cite news |title='I beat pirates with a hose and sonic cannon' |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/6664677.stm |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=2007-04-14 |accessdate=2008-04-22}} }} {{Hijacked ship foot}} ===2006=== {{Hijacked ship head}} {{Hijacked ship |image=[[Image:Suspected pirate ship boarded by USS Winston S. Churchill.jpg|100px|MV Safina ''al-Birsarat'']] |flag=India |owner=India |name={{MV|Safina al-Birsarat}} |class=[[dhow]] |crew=16 |cargo=''coal'' |status=Released |ransom=''none'' |cdate=2006-01-16 |rdate=2006-01-22 |info=Pirates hijacked the India-registered MV ''Safina al-Birsarat'' along with its crew of 16 Indians. On January 22, {{USS|Winston S. Churchill|DDG-81|6}}, an {{sclass-|Arleigh Burke|destroyer}}, intercepted the vessel. After warning shots were fired, the pirates surrendered and all ten onboard were taken into custody. The ten were transported to [[Mombasa]], [[Kenya]] where they were sentenced to seven years in prison by a court.{{cite news|title=Suspected Pirates Captured Off Somali Coast |url=http://www.navy.mil/search/display.asp?story_id=22026 |publisher=[[United States Navy]] |date=2007-01-22 |accessdate=2008-04-26}}{{cite news|title=U.S. Steps Up War Against Somali Pirates |url=http://www.somalilandtimes.net/sl/2005/213/23.shtml |publisher=''The Somali Times'' |date=2006-02-11 |accessdate=2008-04-26}}{{cite news|title=Jail sentence for Somali pirates |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/6105262.stm |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=2006-11-01 |accessdate=2008-04-26}} }} {{Hijacked ship |image=[[Image:USS Cape St. George missile.jpg|100px|USS ''Cape St. George'']]
[[Image:USS Gonzalez (DDG-66).jpg|100px|USS ''Gonzalez'']] |flag=United States |owner=United States |num=2 |name={{USS|Cape St. George|CG-71}} |class={{sclass-|Ticonderoga|cruiser|1}} |name2={{USS|Gonzalez|DDG-66}} |class2={{sclass-|Arleigh Burke|destroyer|1}} |crew=''unknown'' |cargo=''none'' |status=Attack failed, one pirate killed and twelve captured. |ransom=''none'' |cdate=2006-03-18 |rdate=N/A |info=USS ''Cape St. George'', a {{sclass-|Ticonderoga|cruiser}}, and USS ''Gonzalez'', an {{sclass-|Arleigh Burke|destroyer}}, [[March 18, 2006 incident off Somalia|engaged pirate vessels]] after receiving fire from them. }} {{Hijacked ship foot}} ===2007=== {{Hijacked ship head}} {{Hijacked ship |image= |flag=Saint Vincent and the Grenadines |owner=Saint Vincent and the Grenadines |name={{MV|Rozen}} |class= |crew=12 |cargo=UN food aid |status=Released |ransom=''unknown'' |cdate=2007-02-25 |rdate=2007-04-05 |lat_d=11 |lat_m=50 |lat_s=0 |lat_NS=N |long_d=51 |long_m=35 |long_s=0 |long_EW=E |lname=Ship: MV Rozen, 2007-02-25 |info= Somali pirates with automatic weapons captured the ship, carrying six Kenyans and six Sri Lankans.{{cite web|url=http://www.ecop.info/english/e-sap-net-42.htm|title=MV Rozen|last=Mwangura|first=Andrew|date=2007-03-24|publisher=ECOP-marine|accessdate=2008-12-26}} On February 27, members of the Somali coast guard attempted to take back the ship but failed, and two coast guardsmen were killed. }} {{Hijacked ship |image= |flag=Taiwan |owner=Taiwan |name={{Ship|FV|Ching Fong Hwa 168}} |class=[[fishing vessel]] |crew=15 |cargo=''fish'' |status=Released (one hostage killed) |ransom=[[United States dollar|US$]]1,500,000 |cdate=2007-04-28 |rdate=2007-11-05 |info=The Taiwanese fishing vessel was hijacked on May 28, 2007. The surviving crew of ten Chinese, two Taiwanese and two Filipino crew members was released on November 5 after spending more than six months in captivity. One Chinese crew member was killed by the pirates on May 28 because the ship's owners failed to meet their ransom demands.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/africaCrisis/idUSL15534801|title=TSomali pirates killed Chinese sailor-official|date=2007-11-14|accessdate=2009-04-12|publisher=Reuters | first=Duncan | last=Miriri}} }} {{Hijacked ship |image=[[File:Mavuno I and II.png|100px|FV ''Mavuno No. 1'' and FV ''Mavuno No. 2'']] |flag=Tanzania |owner=South Korea |num=2 |name={{Ship|FV|Mavuno No. 1}} |class=[[fishing vessel]] |name2={{Ship|FV|Mavuno No. 2}} |class2=[[fishing vessel]] |crew=25 |cargo=Fishing equipment |status=''unknown'' |ransom=''none'' |cdate=2007-05-15 |rdate=2007-11-00 |lat_d=1 |lat_m=10 |lat_s=0 |lat_NS=N |long_d=49 |long_m=0 |long_s=0 |long_EW=E |lname=Ships: FV Mavuno No. 1, FV Mavuno No. 2, 2007-05-15 |info=Two Tanzanian-registered ships belonging to Korea's Daechang Fishing were seized about {{convert|210|nmi|km}} off the Somali capital of [[Mogadishu]]. Their 25 crew members (including ten Chinese, four South Koreans, three Vietnamese, four Indonesians and four Indians) were released six months later.{{cite news|url=http://english.peopledaily.com.cn/200705/17/eng20070517_375482.html|title=Crew of hijacked South Korean ships safe: official|date=2007-05-17|accessdate=2008-11-30|publisher=People's Daily Online}} }} {{Hijacked ship |image= |flag=Denmark |owner=Denmark |name={{MV|Danica White}} |class=[[cargo ship]] |crew=5 |cargo=''unknown'' |status=Released

Folmer & Co, paid a ransom of [[United States dollar|US$]]723,000, which was negotiated down from $1.5 million.{{cite news |title=Reports on piracy: Danica White |url=http://www.dma.dk/sw20988.asp |publisher=Danish Maritime Authority |date=2007-11-16 |accessdate=2008-04-22 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite news |first=David |last=Osler |title=Svitzer tug hijacked off Somali coast|url=http://lloydslist.com/ll//news/viewArticle.htm?articleId=20017501599&src=ticker |publisher=LLoyd's List |date=2007-02-04 |accessdate=2008-04-22 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080207035910/http://www.lloydslist.com/ll/news/viewArticle.htm?articleId=20017501599&src=ticker |archivedate = 2008-02-07}} }} {{Hijacked ship |image= |flag=Greece |owner=Greece |name={{Ship|FV|Grecko 2}} |class=[[fishing boat]] |crew= 4+ |cargo=''unknown'' |status=''unknown'' |ransom=''unknown'' |cdate=2007-09-20 |rdate=unknown |info=FV ''Greko 2'' was hijacked {{convert|110|nmi|km}} west of [[Berbera]]. US and German naval vessels shadowed the captured vessel and blockaded the port of [[Bosaso]], where the captured tanker was taken. Eventually, after demanding a ransom, the pirates freed the ship and its crew of 21 on December 12.{{cite news |title=Somali pirates leave Japan-owned ship, crew safe |url=http://africa.reuters.com/wire/news/usnL12187866.html |publisher=[[Reuters]] |date=2007-12-12 |accessdate=2008-04-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071214102619/http://africa.reuters.com/wire/news/usnL12187866.html |archivedate=2007-12-14 |df= }} }} {{Hijacked ship |image=[[File:Almarjan.jpg|100px|MV ''Al Marjan'']] |flag=Comoros |owner=Comoros |name={{MV|Al Marjan}} |class=[[General cargo ship]] |crew= |cargo=2,500 tons of general cargo |status=Released

Williams|DDG-95|6}}.{{cite news |title=Crew of North Korean Pirated Vessel Safe |url=http://www.cusnc.navy.mil/articles/2007/226.html |publisher=[[U.S. Naval Forces Central Command]] |date=2007-10-30 |accessdate=2008-04-22 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080312131021/http://www.cusnc.navy.mil/articles/2007/226.html |archivedate = 2008-03-12}} }} {{Hijacked ship foot}} ===2008=== {{Further information|List of ships attacked by Somali pirates in 2008}} ===2009=== {{Further information|List of ships attacked by Somali pirates in 2009}} ===2010=== {{Further information|List of ships attacked by Somali pirates in 2010}} ===2011=== {{Further information|List of ships attacked by Somali pirates in 2011}} ===2012=== {{Further information|List of ships attacked by Somali pirates in 2012}} ===2013=== {{Hijacked ship head}} {{Hijacked ship |image= |flag=Hong Kong |owner=United Kingdom |name=''Island Splendor'' |class= |crew= |cargo=Oil |status=Attack failed. |ransom=''unknown'' |cdate=2013-10-11 |rdate= Attack failed. |info=On 11 October at 0918 UTC, pirates in two skiffs fired upon the tanker ''Island Splendor'' and attempted a boarding approximately {{convert|237|nmi|km}} east of Hobyo, Somalia. The armed security team aboard the tanker fired flares and warning shots, whereupon the pirates returned fire with an automatic weapons. The security team engaged the pirates which resulted in the skiffs aborting the attack.{{cite web|url= http://navalmatters.wordpress.com/tag/island-splendor/ |title= Attempted Boarding by Somali Pirates |date= 18 October 2013 |work=[[Naval Matters]] |accessdate=22 Oct 2013}} }} {{Hijacked ship |image= |flag=Spain |owner=Spain |name= |class= |crew= |cargo=fish |status= |ransom=''unknown'' |cdate=2013-10-14 |rdate= |info={{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/africa/suspected-somali-pirates-captured-by-navyled-forces-after-attack-on-supertanker-8894344.html |title=Suspected Somali pirates captured by Navy-led forces after attack on supertanker |date= 21 October 2013 |work=[[The Independent]] |accessdate=22 Oct 2013}} }} {{Hijacked ship foot}} ===2017=== {{Hijacked ship head}} {{Hijacked ship |image= |flag=Comoros |owner=United Arab Emirates |name=''Aris 13'' |class=[[chemical tanker]] |crew=8 |cargo=''Fuel'' |status=Released |ransom=No ransom paid |cdate=2017-03-13 |rdate=2017-03-16 |lat_d=11 |lat_m=48 |lat_s=30.4914 |lat_NS=N |long_d=43 |long_m=15 |long_s=7.596 |long_EW=E |info=On 13 March 2017, ''Aris 13'', was hijacked by pirates in two skiffs a few miles off [[Alula, Somalia|Alula]], the northernmost town of Somalia in [[Puntland]]. It was the first hijacking of a large commercial vessel since 2012. The ship was taking oil from [[Djibouti]] to the Somali capital, Mogadishu. ''Aris 13'' was boarded by about two dozen armed men, who immediately turned off its tracking system after a distress call was sent from the ship. They then anchored her off Alula.{{cite web|url= https://www.reuters.com/article/us-somalia-hijack-idUSKBN16L0EW?il=0 |title= Somali pirates suspected of hijacking ship after long layoff, expert says |date= 14 March 2017 |work=[[Reuters]] |accessdate=14 Mar 2017}}{{cite web|url= http://bigstory.ap.org/article/7e0b3f0d717a4cdcb50f7dd855db8190/pirates-hijack-freighter-somalias-coast-officials-say |title= Pirates hijack freighter off Somalia's coast, officials say |date= 14 Mar 2017 |work=[[The Associated Press]] |accessdate=14 Mar 2017}}{{cite web|url= https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/03/14/520109265/somali-pirates-reportedly-seize-tanker-in-first-commercial-hijacking-since-2012 |title= Somali Pirates Reportedly Seize Tanker In First Commercial Hijacking Since 2012 |date= 14 Mar 2017 |work=[[NPR]] |accessdate=14 Mar 2017}}{{cite web|url= https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-39264343 |title= Somali pirates suspected of first ship hijacking since 2012 |date= 14 Mar 2017 |work=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=14 Mar 2017}} On 16 March an intense gunfight started between the pirates and the [[Puntland Maritime Police Force]], followed by intense negotiations between the marine force, local clan elders and the pirates, effectively ending the hijacking later that day. The crew was released unharmed. The pirates allegedly agreed to forego a ransom after learning that Somali businessmen had hired ''Aris 13''. Pirates have traditionally been wary of tangling with Somalia's powerful businessmen. The ship had not followed the industry's [[Best Management Practices]] that might have prevented a hijacking. It travelled close to the shore at low speed.See: [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/mar/16/somali-pirates-release-oil-tanker-and-crew-after-first-hijack-for-five-years Somali pirates release oil tanker and crew after first hijack for five years], The Guardian, 16 March 2017. Accessed on 21 March 2017.See: [http://edition.cnn.com/2017/03/17/africa/somali-pirate-mt-aris-13-crew-released/ Crew released without ransom after ship hijacked off Somalia], CNN, 17 March 2017. Accessed on 21 March 2017. }} {{Hijacked ship |image= |flag=Tuvalu |owner=Japan |name={{ship||OS 35}} |class=[[Bulk carrier]] |crew=18 |cargo=Bulk |status=Released |ransom=None |cdate=2017-04-10 |rdate=2017-04-11 |lat_d=12 |lat_m=51 |lat_s=0 |lat_NS=N |long_d=50 |long_m=42 |long_s=0 |long_EW=E |lname=Ship: MV OS 35, 2017-04-10 |info= {{ship||OS 35}} was a loaded bulk carrier en route from Port Kelang to Aden with armed security guards on board. However, the latter and evasive manouvers could not prevent three presumed Somalian pirates from boarding and hijacking the ship. However, the security alert sent by the ship alerted Indian and Chinese navy ships patrolling in the vicinity, who then embarked on a joint rescue operation. 18 Chinese navy personnel subsequently boarded the hijacked ship under a security air cover provided by the Indian Navy, and rescued the hijacked ship.{{cite news |title=Chinese Navy Hands Pirates Over to Somali Authorities |url=https://www.maritime-executive.com/article/chinese-navy-hands-pirates-over-to-somali-authorities |accessdate=22 October 2018 |publisher=Maritime executive |date=8 May 2017}} }} {{Hijacked ship foot}} ===2018=== {{Hijacked ship head}} {{Hijacked ship |image= |flag=Singapore |owner=Singapore |num=1 |name=MT ''Leopard Sun'' |class=[[Chemical tanker|Oil/Chemical tanker]] |crew=''unknown'' |cargo=''unknown'' |status=Attack failed |ransom=''none'' |cdate=2018-10-30 |rdate=N/A |info=In February 2018 MT ''Leopard Sun'' was fired upon by two skiffs {{convert|160|nmi|km}} off the coast of Somalia. The ship's security team returned fire and the ship escaped. This was believed to be the first pirate attack in the area since November 2017.[https://www.reuters.com/article/us-somalia-piracy/chemical-tanker-attacked-off-somalia-pirates-repelled-eu-naval-force-idUSKCN1G725A Chemical tanker attacked off Somalia, pirates repelled: EU Naval force] Reuters, 23 February 2018. {{Other people|Margaret of Austria}} {{Infobox royalty|consort=yes | name = Margaret of Austria | image =Margaret_of_austria_1609.jpg | caption =Portrait by [[Bartolomé González y Serrano]], 1609 | succession =[[List of Spanish consorts|Queen consort of Spain]] and [[List of Portuguese consorts|Portugal]] | reign =18 April 1599 – 3 October 1611 | coronation = | spouse = {{marriage|[[Philip III of Spain]]|18 April 1599}} | issue = [[Anne of Austria|Anne, Queen of France]]
[[Philip IV of Spain|Philip IV, King of Spain]]
[[Maria Anna of Spain|Maria Anna, Holy Roman Empress]]
[[Cardinal-Infante Ferdinand of Austria|Cardinal Ferdinand]] | house =[[House of Habsburg|Habsburg]] | father =[[Charles II of Austria]] | mother =[[Maria Anna of Bavaria (1551–1608)|Maria Anna of Bavaria]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1584|12|25|df=y}} | birth_place =[[Graz]], Austria | death_date = {{death date and age|1611|10|3|1584|12|25|df=y}} | death_place =[[San Lorenzo de El Escorial]], Spain | burial_place=[[El Escorial]] | religion =[[Catholic Church|Roman Catholicism]] }} '''Margaret of Austria''' (25 December 1584 – 3 October 1611) was Queen consort of [[Spain]] and [[Portugal]] by her marriage to King [[Philip III of Spain|Philip III and II]]. ==Life== Margaret was the daughter of [[Charles II of Austria|Archduke Charles II of Austria]] and [[Maria Anna of Bavaria (1551–1608)|Maria Anna of Bavaria]] and thus the paternal granddaughter of the [[Holy Roman Emperor]] [[Ferdinand I, Holy Roman Emperor|Ferdinand I]]. Her elder brother was the [[Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor|Archduke Ferdinand]], who succeeded as Emperor in 1619. Two of her sisters, [[Anna of Austria (1573–1598)|Anna]] and [[Constance of Austria|Constance]], through their subsequent marriages to King [[Sigismund III Vasa]], became [[List of Polish consorts|Queens of Poland]]. ===Queen of Spain=== [[File:Coat of Arms of Margaret of Austria (1584-1611), Queen Consort of Spain.svg|thumb||160px|Coat of arms of Margaret of Austria, Queen of Spain.]] Margaret married [[Philip III of Spain]], her first-cousin, once-removed, on 18 April 1599. She became a very influential figure at her husband's court. Philip had an "affectionate, close relationship" with Margaret, and paid her additional attention after she bore him a son in 1605.Sánchez, p. 100. Margaret was also a great patron of the arts. She was considered by contemporaries{{Who|date=May 2010}} to be a very pious Catholic and "astute and very skillful" in her political dealings.Sánchez, p. 98-99. Alongside the [[Maria of Austria, Holy Roman Empress|Empress Maria]], widow of [[Holy Roman Emperor]] [[Maximilian II, Holy Roman Emperor|Maximilian II]], and the latter's daughter Archduchess [[Archduchess Margaret of Austria (1567–1633)|Margaret]], who lived as a nun in Madrid, Queen Margaret formed a circle of women wielding considerable influence over the king.Sánchez, p.91. They emphasised Spain's status as a [[Catholic]] power acting in the interest of Catholic Europe and also highlighted the unity of the [[House of Habsburg]]. They were successful, for example, in convincing Philip to provide financial support to Holy Roman Emperor [[Ferdinand II, Holy Roman Emperor|Ferdinand II]]. The pro-Austrian camp at the Spanish court was opposed by the [[Francisco Gómez de Sandoval y Rojas, Duke of Lerma|Duke of Lerma]], the King's chief minister, who argued that Spain should pursue her own course of action independently of religious or dynastic ties. Queen Margaret was "melancholic" and unhappy about the influence of Duke, whom she considered corrupt, over her husband, and continually fought him for influence over the king. In this conflict, she was supported by her favourite Mariana de San José, prioress of the ''Monasteria la Encarnación'', her husband's [[confessor]] Father Luis de Aliaga, and her daughter [[Maria Anna of Spain|Maria Anna]]'s confessor, the Franciscan friar Juan de Santa María - who was felt by contemporaries{{Who|date=May 2010}} to have an excessive influence over the King at the end of his life.Sánchez, p.97. The Duke of Lerma was eventually removed from power in 1618, though only after Margaret's death. Margaret died while giving birth to her youngest child, Alfonso. Her husband never remarried and died ten years later. ==Issue== Margaret and Philip had eight children: *[[Anne of Austria|Anna Maria Mauricia]] (22 September 1601 – 20 January 1666), queen of France *Maria (1 February 1603 -2 February 1603) *[[Philip IV of Spain|Philip]] (8 April 1605 – 17 September 1665), king of Spain *[[Maria Anna of Spain|Maria Anna]] (18 August 1606 – 13 May 1646), empress of the Holy Roman Empire *[[Archduke Charles of Austria (1607–1632)|Charles]] (14 September 1607 – 30 July 1632) *[[Cardinal-Infante Ferdinand of Austria|Ferdinand]] (16 May 1609 – 9 November 1641), a cardinal *Margaret Frances (24 May 1610 – 11 March 1617) *Alphonse Maurice (22 September 1611 – 16 September 1612) ==Ancestors== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1= 1. Maria II.svg }} ''[[Don (honorific)|Dona]]'' '''Maria II''' (4 April 1819 – 15 November 1853) "the Educator" ({{lang-pt|"a Educadora"}}) or "the Good Mother" ({{lang-pt|"a Boa Mãe"}}), reigned as [[Queen of Portugal]] from 1826 to 1828, and again from 1834 to 1853. Born in [[Rio de Janeiro]], she was the first child of Emperor [[Pedro I of Brazil]] and his first wife, [[Maria Leopoldina of Austria|Empress Maria Leopoldina]] and thus a member of the [[House of Braganza]]. One of the two surviving children born when Pedro was still [[heir apparent]] to Portugal, she inherited Portuguese titles and was placed in the [[line of succession to the former Portuguese throne]], even after becoming a member of the [[Brazilian Imperial Family]], from which she was excluded in 1835 after her definitive ascension to the Portuguese throne. == Early life == ===Birth=== Maria II was born ''Maria da Glória Joana Carlota Leopoldina da Cruz Francisca Xavier de Paula Isidora Micaela Gabriela Rafaela Gonzaga''{{sfn|Sousa|1972a|p=112}} at 4 April 1819 in the [[Paço de São Cristóvão|Palace of São Cristóvão]] in [[Rio de Janeiro]], [[Kingdom of Brazil]]. She was the eldest daughter of the [[Pedro I of Brazil|Prince Pedro de Alcântara]], future [[List of Portuguese monarchs|King of Portugal]] as Pedro IV and first [[List of Brazilian monarchs|Emperor of Brazil]] as Pedro I, and his first wife [[Maria Leopoldina of Austria|Maria Leopoldina]] (née Archduchess Caroline Josepha Leopoldine of Austria), herself a daughter of [[Francis II, Holy Roman Emperor]]. She was titled [[Princess of Beira]] upon her birth. Born in [[Brazil]], Maria was the only European monarch to have been born outside of Europe, though she was still born in Portuguese territory. === Succession crisis === The death of Maria's grandfather, [[João VI of Portugal|King João VI]], in March 1826 sparked a succession crisis in Portugal. The king had a male heir, [[Pedro I of Brazil|Pedro]], but Pedro had proclaimed the independence of [[Brazil]] in 1822 with himself as Emperor. The late king also had a younger son, [[Miguel of Portugal|Miguel]], but he was exiled to Austria after leading a number of revolutions against his father and his liberal regime. Before his death, the king had nominated his favourite daughter, [[Infanta Isabel Maria of Portugal|Isabel Maria]], to serve as [[regent]] until "the legitimate heir returned to the kingdom" — but he had failed to specify which of his sons was the legitimate heir: Pedro, the liberal [[Emperor of Brazil]], or Miguel, the [[Absolute monarchy|absolutist]] exiled prince. Most people considered Pedro to be the legitimate heir, but Brazil did not want him to unite Portugal and Brazil's thrones again. Aware that his brother's supporters were ready to bring Miguel back and put him on the throne, Pedro decided for a more consensual option: he would renounce his claim to the Portuguese throne in favour of his daughter Maria (who was only seven years old), and that she was to marry her uncle Miguel, who would accept the liberal constitution and act as a regent until his niece reached majority. Miguel pretended to accept, but upon his arrival in Portugal he immediately deposed Maria and proclaimed himself king, abrogating the liberal constitution in the process. During his reign of terror, Maria traveled to many European courts, including her maternal grandfather's in [[Vienna]], as well as London and Paris. === Absolutist uprising === [[File:Maria II Portugal 1829.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Maria II at age 10, 1829]] Maria's first reign was interrupted by the absolutist uprising led by her uncle, fiancé and regent Miguel, who proclaimed himself King of Portugal on 23 June 1828. Then began the [[Liberal Wars]] that lasted until 1834, the year in which Maria was restored to the throne and Miguel exiled to Germany. The [[Marquis of Barbacena]], arriving in [[Gibraltar]] with the princess on 3 September 1828, was informed by an emissary of what was happening in Portugal. He had the foresight to understand that Miguel had come from Vienna determined to put himself at the head of the absolutist movement, advised by [[Klemens von Metternich|Prince Klemens von Metternich]], who was directing European politics, and so it was dangerous for the young Queen to go to Vienna. Taking responsibility, he changed the direction of the journey, and departed for [[London]], where he arrived on 7 October. English policy was not conducive to its purpose. The [[Duke of Wellington]]'s office openly sponsored Miguel, so the asylum the Marquis had sought was not safe. Maria II was received in court with the honors due to her high hierarchy, but the British prevented their subjects there emigres to go to reinforce the garrison of the island Terceira. Miguel's coup d'état had not gone unrevealed. On 16 May 1828, the garrison of Porto revolted, and in Lagos an infantry battalion. The revolts were stifled. Saldanha, Palmela, and others, who had come to take charge of the movement in Porto, re-embarked on ''Belfast'' ship, which had brought them; the Porto garrison, reinforced by the academic volunteers of [[Coimbra]] and other liberal troops, emigrated to [[Galiza]] and from there to [[England]]. At the head of a small liberal expedition, the [[Marquis of Saldanha]] attempted to disembark in Terceira, [[Azores]], but was not allowed to take the English cruise, whose vigilance he could not avoid for some time after the Count of Vila Flor, later of Terceira, was able to disembark. In time, because in August 1829 appeared in front of the island a huge Miguelist squad that sent to soil a body of disembarkation. Then there was the Battle of August 11 in the village of Praia, where the miguelists were defeated. When the emigrants in England received the news of the victory, they felt great enthusiasm. They soon lost hope of knowing that the young queen was returning to the [[Brazilian Empire]] to her father. In fact, the situation of Maria II in the English court, next to the ministry in the power, became embarrassing and humiliating. The Queen left London to meet her future stepmother, [[Amélie of Leuchtenberg]]. They left together on 30 August 1829 for [[Rio de Janeiro]], arriving on 16 October. The constitutional cause was thought to have been lost. The dispersed emigres (France, England and Brazil) were divided into rival factions. Only Terceira Island recognized the constitutional principles, and even there appeared miguelists guerillas. France was ready to recognize Miguel's government when the revolution of July broke out in Paris in 1830, which encouraged the Portuguese liberals. === Civil War === [[File:A Carta Constitucional e a família real.png|thumb|right|The Constitutional Charter of 1826 and the Royal Family.]] In 7 April 1831, Pedro I abdicated the imperial crown of Brazil on behalf of his son [[Pedro II of Brazil|Pedro II]], Maria's younger brother, and came to Europe with his daughter and his second wife, to support his daughter's rights to the crown from Portugal and joined the forces loyal to Maria in the [[Azores]] in their [[Liberal Wars|war against Miguel]]. He took the title of [[Duke of Braganza]], and Regent in her name. Almost at the same time the regency of the [[Ilha Terceira]], named by Pedro and composed of the [[Marquis of Palmela]], the Count of Vila Flor and José António Guerreiro, prepared an expedition that soon took possession of the [[Azores]]. While extending the constitutional territory, Pedro disembarked in [[France]], being welcomed with sympathy by the new government and by [[Louis Philippe I]]. Miguel's government had defied the immunities of French subjects, had not at once satisfied the complaints of the French government, which had sent a squadron commanded by Admiral Roussin to force the bar of Lisbon and impose humiliating conditions of peace. Pedro left his daughter in [[Paris]] to finish her education, delivered to her stepmother, [[Amélie of Leuchtenberg|Empress Amélie]], with good masters, and left for the Azores at the head of an expedition organized on the island of Belle Isle, bringing his supporters together. Arriving in the Azores on 3 March 1832, he formed a new ministry, assembled a small army, whose command he gave to the Count of Vila Flor, and carried him aboard a squadron which he delivered to the English officer Sartorius, and departed for mainland Portugal. July 8 at Memória Beach in [[Matosinhos]]. It was followed by the [[Siege of Porto]] and a series of battles until, on 24 July 1833, the [[Duke of Terceira]] entered victorious in Lisbon, having won the [[Battle of Cova da Piedade]] the day before. Porto and Lisbon, the main cities, were in the power of the liberals. Pedro came to Lisbon, and summoned his daughter from Paris, forcing his brother, [[Miguel I of Portugal|Miguel]] to [[Concession of Evoramonte|abdicate in 1834]]. Maria was thereupon restored to the throne, and obtained an annulment of her betrothal. Soon after her restoration to the throne, her father died from tuberculosis. On 7 February 1833, in order to protect the Queen, the [[2nd Lancers Regiment (Portugal)|2nd Lancers Regiment]] was created, first known as the ''Regimento de Lanceiros da Rainha'' (Queen's Lancers Regiment), with the motto ''Morte ou Glória'', "Death or Glory" (the same as the 17th Lancers, since Lt. Col. Sir Anthony Bacon was its first commander), a fortunate coincidence since the queen's name was Maria da Glória. Occupying the Portuguese throne, Maria II was still [[heir presumptive]] to her brother Pedro II as [[Princess Imperial of Brazil]], until her exclusion from the Brazilian line of succession by law no. 91 of 30 October 1835. == Consolidation == === Reign === [[File:Maria II 1852.png|thumb|left|190px|Queen Maria II, around age 33, one year before her death, c. 1852. Painting by Sir [[William Charles Ross]].]] [[File:500 Réis à l'effigie de Marie II, 1849.jpg|thumb|right|Effigy of Maria II, 1849]] Maria married [[Auguste de Beauharnais, 2nd Duke of Leuchtenberg|Auguste, Duke of Leuchtenberg]], son of [[Eugène de Beauharnais]], and grandson of [[Joséphine de Beauharnais|Empress Josephine]] on 26 January 1835, at the age of fifteen. However, he died only two months later, on 28 March 1835. On 9 April 1836, she married the cultured and able [[Ferdinand II of Portugal|Prince Ferdinand of Saxe-Coburg and Gotha]]. In accordance with Portuguese law, Ferdinand received the title of king upon the birth of their first child and heir, [[Pedro V of Portugal|Peter]]. In 1842, [[Pope Gregory XVI]] presented Maria with a [[Golden Rose]]. Maria's reign saw a revolutionary insurrection on 16 May 1846, but this was crushed by royalist troops on 22 February 1847, and Portugal otherwise avoided the European [[Revolution of 1848]]. Maria's reign was also notable for a public health act aimed at curbing the spread of [[cholera]] throughout the country. She also pursued policies aimed at raising the levels of education throughout the country. ===Death=== [[File:São Vicente de Fora (versão colorida de gravura de 1854, Manuel Maria Bordalo Pinheiro).png|thumb|Arrival of the funeral procession of Maria II to the [[Monastery of São Vicente de Fora]].]] From her first pregnancy, at the age of eighteen, Maria II faced problems in giving birth, with prolonged and extremely difficult labor. An example of this was her third gestation, whose labor lasted 32 hours, after which a girl was baptized in articulo mortis with the name of Maria (1840). At 25 years of age and in her fifth gestation, the sovereign became obese and her births became even more complicated. In 1847 the fetal distress that preceded the birth of her eighth son – the [[Infante Augusto, Duke of Coimbra]] – brought to the world a child "quite purple and with little breathing". The dangerous routine of successive pregnancies, coupled with obesity (which eventually caused her heart problems) and the frequency of dystocic births (worrisome, especially as a multiparous woman) led doctors to warn the queen about the serious risks she would face in future pregnancies. Indifferent to the warnings, Maria II merely replied: "If I die, I die at my post." On 15 November 1853, thirteen hours after the onset of labor of the stillborn infant Eugenio, her 11th son, Maria II died at the age of 34. The announcement of death was published in the Government Gazette of November 16, 1853: {{quote|Paço das Necessidades, November 15, 1853, at half an hour after noon. Her Majesty the Queen began to notice announcements of childbirth at nine-thirty on the night of the day. Difficulties appeared in the progress of the same childbirth, which forced the doctors to resort to operations, for which the extraction of an infant was obtained, of time, which received the baptism before being extracted. The result of these operations took place at ten o'clock in the morning. Unfortunately, after an hour and a half, Her Majesty, exhausted from all strength, declared "I surrender my soul to God after having received all the sacraments."}} In a letter dated November 28, 1853, the Duchess of Ficalho, the queen's maid, reported the outcome to her brother, the 2nd Earl of Lavradio: {{quote|At two o'clock after midnight from the 14th to the 15th, I was ordered to go to the Palace, where I arrived at about three o'clock. I found the Empress in the Queen's room, where I immediately entered, thinking Her Majesty troubled and even little then we left the immediate room and asked TeixeiraManuel Carlos Teixeira, professor of the Medical-Surgical School of Lisbon and 1st private surgeon of the Royal Chamber (1856), dean of the Royal Hospital of S. I did not like it, and it was like that, until Teixeira called the doctors, who were out and who had not seen the Queen, and as soon as they examined her, the horrible operation was decided: the doctors were Teixeira, Farto,António Joaquim Farto was a surgeon at the Royal Hospital of St. Joseph (1797), a surgeon who was accorded the honors of the royal surgeon (1827), a nobleman of the Royal House (1827), director of the Medical-Surgical School of Lisbon (1830) and 1st surgeon of the Royal Chamber (1837). He passed away in October 1856. Kessler,Dr. Friedrich Kessler (1804–1872), Doctor of Medicine and the personal physician to King Fernando II. He was made a partner of the Royal Academy of Sciences of Lisbon and 1st Baron of Kessler (1855). Kessler immediately dismissed the case as very dangerous. The operation was begun. I climbed onto the bed. On the right side, the Empress, full of tears; the Queen, with no fainting, but with a very bad opinion, and, complaining that she was suffering enough, said in her natural voice: "O Teixeira, if I am in danger, tell me, do not deceive me."}} Queen Maria II is remembered as a good mother and a kind person who always acted according to her convictions in her attempt to help her country. She was later given the [[List of monarchs by nickname|nickname]] "The Good Mother." ==Marriages and issue== Maria first married [[Auguste de Beauharnais, 2nd Duke of Leuchtenberg|Auguste Charles, 2nd Duke of Leuchtenberg]], son of [[Eugène de Beauharnais]], grandson of [[Joséphine de Beauharnais|Empress Josephine]], who died soon after arriving in Portugal. The '''Marusia massacre''' ({{lang-es|Masacre de Marusia}}) (March, 1925) was the response of the [[Chile]]an government under president [[Arturo Alessandri]] to a [[Strike action|strike]] by the workers of a [[Sodium nitrate|saltpeter]] mine leading to over 500 dead, over ninety percent being strikers or their family members.
== Background == The nitrate ''oficina'' (saltpeter mine) of Marusia was located in the foothills of the Andes in the [[región de Tarapacá]], about 4½ miles northwest of the town of [[Huara]]. Its monthly production was 865 tons of salt.<ref>{{cite book|author=Risopatrón, Luis|title=Diccionario geográfico de Chile|year=1924|page=532|publisher=Imprenta Universitaria}}</ref> On March 1925, the mine workers went on strike to demand higher pay, a shorter workday, and better working conditions. While the negotiations were taking place between the company executives and the worker's representatives, the British engineer who ran the mine, a man much hated because of his habit of whipping his workers, was found dead near the mine. A Bolivian engineer was accused of the crime and executed without due process by decision of the company owners.
==Events== The union, under the leadership of Domingo Soto, was afraid of reprisals, and especially of another [[massacre]] like the one that had happened only a few years before in [[San Gregorio massacre|San Gregorio]], so they decided to take several preventive measures. They contacted the other mines, and proposed to blow up the railroad tracks in order to prevent the arrival of strikebreakers. The government, upon being apprised of the unrest, responded by sending forty soldiers under the command of captain [[Gilberto Troncoso]], known as the "''Hyena of San Gregorio''" for his violent behaviour.
The women of Marusia organized themselves under the leadership of [[Selva Saavedra]], and decided to resist the advance of the troops. When the soldiers arrived, they entered the town shooting. A group of workers responded by throwing [[dynamite]] sticks at them, killing several soldiers and seizing their guns. Then the workers mounted a counteroffensive, taking over the explosives depot of the mine and cutting the telegraphic wires. Captain Troncoso was forced to retreat.
The miners proceeded to arm the whole town (about 2,400 people). In an open assembly, the union leaders proposed to negotiate their surrender, while some miners advocated calling upon the help of the workers from other mines. In the end, a motion by Soto that the town priest be asked to mediate was adopted.
The army reinforcements arrived in the form of a 300-man battalion under the command of Colonel [[Pedro Schultz]]. They attacked the town in the middle of the night and machine-gunned everyone in sight. Hundreds died, including women and children — the exact number was never properly established. A group of workers were able to mount a hasty defense, throwing dynamite sticks at the advancing troops, and they managed to kill 36 soldiers and to injure 64. The surviving miners escaped with their families into the high mountains. This put an end to the immediate strike, but the conflict flared again less than two months later, and led to the [[La Coruña massacre]].
==Popular culture==
The film titled ''[[Letters from Marusia]]'' is based on a [[Patricio Manns]] novel (1974) inspired by these events.

'''Jeffrey Howe''' (1960 – March 8, 2009) was a British businessman who was murdered by Stephen Marshall.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/feb/01/jigsaw-man-murder-gangster-killings</ref> His dismembered body parts were scattered across [[Hertfordshire]] and [[Leicestershire]], leading to him being known in the press as '''Jigsaw Man'''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2009/apr/24/body-parts-victim|title=Body parts victim identified as kitchen salesman|last=Tran|first=Mark|date=24 April 2009|work=The Guardian|accessdate=2 February 2010 | location=London}}</ref> Marshall became known as the '''Jigsaw Killer'''. Marshall initially pleaded "not guilty" to murder, but changed his plea to "guilty" and was sentenced to life imprisonment in February 2010.<ref name=justice>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1247710/Jigsaw-killer-Stephen-Marshall-spend-36-years-jail-Jeffrey-Howes-murder.html|title=Jigsaw killer's admission that he disposed of four other bodies could bring crime family to justice|last=Levy|first=Andrew|author2=Tamara Cohen|date=2 February 2010|work=[[The Daily Mail]]|accessdate=2 February 2010 | location=London}}</ref>
==Background== Jeffrey Howe, 49, was a kitchen salesman. He had worked around the country and had been a chef in Italy, and was a Manchester United football supporter. His brother described him as "a jovial, charming character who had a heart of gold and would get on with anyone."<ref name=quizzed/> He had twice been married.<ref name=money>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/crime/6982696/Jigsaw-murder-Couple-murdered-salesman-for-his-money.html|title=Jigsaw murder: 'Couple murdered salesman for his money'|last=Evans|first=Martin|date=13 January 2010|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=3 February 2010 | location=London}}</ref> Neighbours said that he was aggressive and argued about children playing, and said they had not seen him or his two Jaguar cars for about six months, believing that he rented out his ground floor two-bedroom flat.<ref name=pa>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/feedarticle/8471232|title=Police quiz two over jigsaw murder|date=24 April 2009|work=Press Association|accessdate=3 February 2010 | location=London}}</ref><ref name=solved/>
Stephen Marshall, 38, was a body builder, personal trainer and former bouncer<ref name=justice/> of Ayot Path, [[Borehamwood]], Hertfordshire, and formerly of Park Street, [[St Albans]],<ref name=steal/> where he once owned a gym.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hertsad.co.uk/content/herts/news/story.aspx?brand=HADOnline&category=News&tBrand=HertsCambsOnline&tCategory=newslatestHAD&itemid=WEED01%20Feb%202010%2013%3A33%3A36%3A973|title=Jigsaw body parts trial: life for St Albans murderer Marshall|date=1 February 2010|work=The Herts Advertiser|accessdate=3 February 2010}}</ref> He was a work associate and lodger of Howe's at his flat in Southgate, London.<ref name=butchered>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/8465776.stm|title='Jigsaw man' butchered by lodger who wanted his life|last=Shah|first=Druti|date=1 February 2010|work=BBC News|accessdate=3 February 2010}}</ref> Marshall had lived at the Southgate flat since November 2008<ref name=friends>{{cite news |url=http://www.edp24.co.uk/news/jury_hears_from_victim_s_friends_in_body_parts_murder_trial_1_294318 |title=Jury Hears From Victim's Friends In Body Parts Murder Trial |date=15 January 2010 |work=EDP24 |accessdate=9 October 2011}}</ref> after Howe, said to be his 'drinking buddy', wanted to help him out.<ref name=buddy>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/8461627.stm|title=Cut-up salesman was murder accused's 'drinking buddy'|date=15 January 2010|work=BBC News|accessdate=3 February 2010}}</ref> He stayed without paying rent along with his girlfriend Sarah Bush, 21, from Southgate, who was a prostitute.<ref name=identity>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/jan/13/jigsaw-man-murder|title=Couple killed 'jigsaw man' to steal his identity, court hears|last=Pidd|first=Helen|date=13 January 2010|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=2 February 2010 | location=London}}</ref><ref name=bodies/> They stole Howe's food and refused to leave after promising to do so,<ref name=jailed/> which he complained about to a friend at Christmas time.<ref name=friends/> They fraudulently claimed [[housing benefit]] by forging his signature, saying he was leasing the property to them.<ref name=identity/>
Sarah Bush met Marshall when he hired her as a prostitute. He made her change her name from Sara.<ref name=butchered/> She spent most of her childhood in care, and has two children.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.borehamwoodtimes.co.uk/news/4883866.First_pictures_of_jigsaw_murderer_s_lover/|title=First pictures of jigsaw murderer's lover|last=Barham|first=Alexandra|date=1 February 2010|work=Borehamwood Times|accessdate=3 February 2010}}</ref> Her first baby, which she had when she had just turned 15, died aged 10 days.<ref name=gangster>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2010/feb/01/jigsaw-man-murder-gangster-killings|title='Jigsaw man' murderer says he cut up other bodies in gangster killings|last=Pidd|first=Helen|date=1 February 2010|work=The Guardian|accessdate=3 February 2010 | location=London}}</ref>
==Murder== Howe was murdered on the night of 8–9 March 2009.<ref name=identity/> He was stabbed twice in the back with a 4-inch blade, one of the wounds puncturing his lung.<ref name=justice/><ref name=butchered/> Howe may have been alive for up to an hour after he was stabbed.<ref name=butchered/> Marshall "skillfully and cleanly" removed Howe's limbs,<ref name=bodies/> which Home Office pathologist Simon Poole estimated would have taken at least 12 hours.<ref name=butchered/>
After the murder, Marshall and Bush used Howe's bank account, buying a [[laptop]], shoes, takeaways,<ref name=gangster/> and other consumer goods and food. They set up an account with online retailer [[Littlewoods]], some of the purchases being made on a computer in St. Albans library.<ref name=steal/> They wrote forged cheques to clear his account.<ref name=steal>{{cite news|url=http://www.enfieldindependent.co.uk/news/4849375.Prosecution___They_killed_him_to_steal_/|title=Prosecution: 'They killed him to steal'|last=Lewis|first=Alex|date=13 January 2010|work=Enfield Independent|accessdate=3 February 2010}}</ref> They sold some of his belongings, including his mobile phone, furniture, and his [[Saab Automobile|Saab]] car, which was sold on [[eBay]].<ref name=jailed/> They said to Howe's friend Shehrya Khan that he had "packed up and left."<ref name=friends/><ref name=jailed/> Howe's adopted brother John visited the flat on 28 March and was told by Bush that Howe had not collected rent for a while and had left with his belongings.<ref name=buddy/>
===Discovery of his body=== * '''22 March'''. A left leg with the foot attached was found in a lay-by on the A507 in [[Cottered]], [[Hertfordshire]], wrapped in blue plastic bags.<ref name=justice/> A murder investigation was launched.<ref name=timeline>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/politics/lawandorder/5210130/Timeline-of-police-investigation-to-identify-dismembered-man-Jeffrey-Howe.html |title=Timeline of police investigation to identify dismembered man Jeffrey Howe |date=24 April 2009 |work=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=2 February 2010 |location=London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427170314/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/politics/lawandorder/5210130/Timeline-of-police-investigation-to-identify-dismembered-man-Jeffrey-Howe.html |archivedate=April 27, 2009 }}</ref> * '''29 March'''. A left forearm, dismembered at the elbow and wrist, was found on a grass verge along Drovers Lane, [[Wheathampstead]].<ref name=timeline/><ref name=albans/> * '''31 March'''. A head was unearthed<ref name=reuters/> by a farmer in a cattle pen in a field in [[Asfordby]], [[Leicestershire]].<ref name=timeline/> The flesh had been removed and the eyes, ears, tongue and neck had been cut off.<ref name=admits/> * '''7 April'''. A right leg was found in a holdall near the A10 [[Puckeridge]] bypass in Hertfordshire by a driver.<ref name=timeline/> * '''11 April'''. A torso, right arm and upper left arm were discovered in a ditch by a walker near [[Standon, Hertfordshire]] inside a green suitcase, the same brand as the holdall.<ref name=timeline/><ref name=reuters/> * His hands have not been found, though Bush has said they were buried in [[Epping Forest]].<ref name=butchered/><ref name=identity/>
==Investigation== Detective Superintendent Michael Hanlon from the Bedfordshire and Hertfordshire Major Crime Unit led the investigation,<ref name=jailed/> named Operation Abnet and involving up to 100 officers.<ref name=quizzed>{{cite news|url=http://www.thelondondailynews.com/southgate-jigsaw-flatmates-still-quizzed-p-2781.html|title=Who was Southgate Jigsaw man? – Flatmates still quizzed|date=24 April 2009|work=London Daily News|accessdate=3 February 2010}}</ref> To aid the investigation, police revealed that the victim was overweight, suffered from eczema, had bleached skin pigmentation on his legs, a fungal infection on his toenails,<ref name=timeline/> and was missing two front teeth.<ref name=solved>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/politics/lawandorder/5210489/Identity-of--jigsaw-body-parts-murder-victim-solved.html |title=Identity of 'jigsaw' body parts murder victim solved |last=Irvine |first=Chris |author2=Murray Wardrop |date=24 April 2009 |work=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=3 February 2010 |location=London |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090427125934/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/politics/lawandorder/5210489/Identity-of--jigsaw-body-parts-murder-victim-solved.html |archivedate=April 27, 2009 }}</ref> They released a picture of the suitcase in which the torso was found.<ref name=timeline/> The police decided to keep details of the dismemberment from the public to avoid panic.<ref name=recall>{{cite news|url=http://www.herald24.co.uk/news/cops_recall_snaring_jigsaw_killer_1_89430|title=Cops recall snaring ‘jigsaw’ killer|last=Christian|first=Paul|date=1 March 2010|work=East Herts Herald|accessdate=5 May 2010}}</ref>
A friend of Howe had visited the flat at the end of January 2009 and found the couple living there. After trying to phone him and hearing he had gone missing, she reported him as a missing person on 15 March.<ref name=friends/> Howe's mother, who usually received calls from him several times a week, rang the incident room some time before 21 April to report Howe missing.<ref name=butchered/><ref name=timeline/> Two police officers went to the flat at 11:30 on the morning of 16 March and forced entry when there was no answer, searching all the rooms. There was no visible sign of blood, and Howe's passport was on a coffee table.<ref name=buddy/> When questioned by police, Marshall and Bush said that as far as they knew he was alive.<ref name=butchered/> The police used dental records to identify Howe from his remains,<ref name=money/> and discovered that Marshall had lived close to where the torso was found.<ref name=recall/> Police arrested the couple at the flat in Southgate, north London on 21 April. The arresting officer said that "[Marshall] was very, very nervous, jittery, his leg was shaking. Sarah Bush was uncomfortable, and at that point I knew that Jeffrey Howe was going to be our victim."<ref name=recall/> Taken to a station in Hertfordshire for questioning,<ref name=timeline/> Bush told police that Marshall suffered "mood swings" and that she had been planning to leave him.<ref name=butchered/> Marshall gave "no comment" to police questioning.<ref name=recall/> Howe was publicly named as the victim on 23 April.<ref name=timeline/>
Blood was found in the bedroom and bathroom of the flat and under the carpet,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article6987050.ece|title=Couple accused of 'jigsaw murder' preyed on victim for money, court hears|last=Fresco|first=Adam|date=14 January 2010|work=The Times|accessdate=2 February 2010|location=London}}</ref> and blood was found in Howe's car after it was recovered.<ref name=identity/> Green fibres from a T-shirt in Marshall's bedroom matched fibres on duct tape used to wrap Howe’s body parts.<ref name=butchered/><ref name=recall/> The journey of Marshall and Bush to Leicestershire was traced from [[CCTV]] and [[Automatic number plate recognition]].<ref name=steal/>
The [[Independent Police Complaints Commission|IPCC]] is supervising a [[Metropolitan Police Service]] review of procedure of how Howe's missing person case was handled.<ref name=butchered/>
==Trial== The trial began on 12 January 2010<ref name=trial>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/8454031.stm|title=Man admits dismembering salesman|date=12 January 2010|work=BBC News|accessdate=3 February 2010}}</ref> and was held at [[List of Crown Court venues in England and Wales|St Albans Crown Court]], with Stuart Trimmer QC prosecuting. Marshall initially denied murdering Howe, claiming that Bush murdered him and that he only helped to dismember and dispose of the body, admitting counts of [[perverting the course of justice]] and intending to prevent a [[coroner]] from holding an [[inquest (England and Wales)|inquest]].<ref name=bodies/> Bush denied all charges.<ref name=trial/>
The court heard that Marshall previously threatened to "get rid of" Bush's previous partner in Epping Forest, and to "dispose of" another woman. He had boasted to her of having "considerable experience of disposing of bodies".<ref name=identity/> She said the first time he did so he was nauseated and took [[cocaine]] to cope, becoming an addict.<ref name=admits/> A witness said that when working for the [[Clerkenwell crime syndicate|Adams crime family]], Marshall had used a meat cleaver, meat knives, a hacksaw, or a chainsaw to cut up bodies.<ref name=jailed/>
A friend of Bush, Sophie Franklin,<ref name=justice/> told the court that when drunk, Bush confessed to friends that she helped Marshall kill Howe after Marshall stabbed him in the back, placing a pillow over Howe's face to stop the noise.<ref name=identity/> Another friend of Bush, Danielle Matthews, said Bush told her she had seen the murder, and that Howe had laughed when Marshall had earlier threatened to kill him unless he left the flat.<ref name=butchered/>
On January 29, three weeks into the trial, Marshall changed his plea to guilty of murder.<ref name=admits>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article7007851.ece|title=Stephen Marshall admits murder of 'jigsaw man', Jeffrey Howe|last=Fresco|first=Adam|date=30 January 2010|work=The Times|accessdate=2 February 2010|location=London}}</ref> He was sentenced to life imprisonment on 1 February, for a minimum of 36 years.<ref name=jailed>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article7011246.ece|title='Jigsaw Man' murderer Stephen Marshall jailed for 36 years|date=1 February 2010|work=The Times|accessdate=2 February 2010|location=London}}</ref> The judge, [[Jeremy Cooke]], said that little credit could be given for the change of plea as the case was so overwhelming.<ref name=albans>{{cite news|last=Lewis|first=Alex|url=http://www.stalbansreview.co.uk/news/4883741.Dramatic_end_to_St_Albans_body_parts_trial/|title=Dramatic end to St Albans body parts trial|date=1 February 2010|work=St. Albans and Harpenden Review|accessdate=3 February 2010}}</ref> He dismissed Marshall's claim that he was on the verge of drug-induced suicide when he stabbed his victim in bed.<ref name=albans/>
Bush also changed her plea to guilty on 1 February,<ref name=jailed/> and was sentenced to three years and nine months for perverting the course of justice by helping Marshall take Howe's head to Leicestershire<ref name=albans/> and was given a concurrent sentence of two years and three months for giving false information about Howe's whereabouts,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/jigsaw-killer-cut-up-four-other-bodies-1886339.html|title=Jigsaw killer 'cut up four other bodies'|date=2 February 2010|work=The Independent|accessdate=2 February 2010 | location=London}}</ref> though she was acquitted of murder.<ref name=reuters>{{cite news|last=MacLellan|first=Kylie|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKTRE6104Z820100201|title="Jigsaw man" killer jailed for life|date=1 February 2010|work=Reuters|accessdate=3 February 2010}}</ref> She will probably serve 18 months.<ref name=herts/>
After the trial it was revealed that Marshall had previous convictions for criminal damage, assault, battery, cocaine possession, and possessing a firearm.<ref name=butchered/> He had attacked his first wife in 2003, and was arrested on suspicion of murdering Minesh Nagrecha in 1996 when his burnt body was found. He was never charged, instead appearing as a witness.<ref name=gangster/> Bush had two prior cautions for possession of cannabis and assault.<ref name=butchered/>
Marshall was refused leave to appeal in October 2010.<ref name=herts>{{cite news|url=http://www.hertsad.co.uk/news/body_parts_murderer_denied_appeal_hearing_1_724838|title=Body parts murderer denied appeal hearing|last=Brannen|first=Aimee|date=12 November 2010|work=The Herts Advertiser|accessdate=9 December 2011}}</ref> A challenge to the length of his sentence was turned down by two Court of Appeal judges in November 2010.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.borehamwoodtimes.co.uk/news/8496363._Horrific__body_parts_murderer_denied_sentence_appeal/|title='Horrific' body parts murderer, Stephen Marshall, of Borehamwood, denied sentence appeal|last=Pears|first=Elizabeth|date=4 November 2010|work=Borehamwood & Elstree Times|accessdate=9 December 2011}}</ref>
===Previous bodies=== Via his lawyer, Peter Doyle, Marshall admitted in court on 1 February to dismembering four more bodies between 1995 and 1998 and disposing of them in Epping Forest,<ref name=bodies>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/uk/crime/article7011599.ece|title=Jigsaw killer Stephen Marshall to be questioned in jail over four bodies|last=Fresco|first=Adam|date=2 February 2010|work=The Times|accessdate=2 February 2010|location=London}}</ref> when he worked for the Adams crime family as a doorman for a London nightclub.<ref name=justice/><ref name=gangster/> This admission was to the surprise of police,<ref name=gangster/> but Marshall refused to give them details of the other victims.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/8561945.stm|title='Jigsaw' killer refuses to name other victims |date=11 March 2010|work=BBC News|accessdate=5 May 2010}}</ref>

[[File:Cemetery Angel 002 HDR.jpg|thumb|right|"Their little souls to the angels flew...."]] '''Obituary poetry''', in the broad sense, includes any [[poetry|poem]] that commemorates a person or group of people's [[death]]: an [[elegy]]. In its stricter sense, though, it refers to a [[poetic genre|genre]] of popular verse or [[folk poetry]] that had its greatest popularity in the nineteenth century, especially in the [[United States of America]]. The genre consists largely of [[sentimentality|sentimental]] [[narrative verse]] that tells the story of the demise of its typically named subjects and seeks to console their [[mourning|mourners]] with descriptions of their happy [[afterlife]]. The genre achieved its peak of popularity in the decade of the 1870s.[[Julia A. Moore]], ''Mortal Refrains: The Complete Collected Poetry, Prose, and Songs of Julia A. Moore, The Sweet Singer of Michigan'' Thomas A. Riedlinger, ed. (Michigan State University Press (1998) {{ISBN|0-87013-449-3}}), p. 6 While usually full chiefly of conventional pious sentiments, the obituary poets in one sense continue the program of meditations on death begun by the eighteenth-century [[graveyard poets]], such as [[Edward Young]]'s ''[[Night Thoughts]]'', and as such continue one of the themes that went into literary [[Romanticism]].See generally, James Stevens Curl, ''The Victorian Celebration of Death'' (Sutton, 2000: {{ISBN|0-7509-2318-0}}), ch. 1 ==Death poetry in the popular press== Obituary poetry constituted a large portion of the poetry published in American newspapersSee generally, Slason Thomson (ed.), ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=tg1RdndkFFwC&dq=%22the+humbler+poets%22&printsec=frontcover&source=bl&ots=hWVpkPOCd9&sig=53IZtWbket-0un3oZUQV_9cWKSE&hl=en&ei=3ixmSpiWDZPIMPaO6ZsB&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1 The Humbler Poets: A Collection of Newspaper and Periodical Verse]'' (Jansen McClug &Co., 1886) in the nineteenth century.[[Walter Blair (academic)|Walter Blair]], ''Essays on American humor: Blair through the ages'', Hamlin Lewis Hill, ed. (Univ of Wisconsin Press, 1993; {{ISBN|0-299-13624-8}}), p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=v3zxIZ7tPWsC&pg=PA109&lpg=PA109&dq=%22obituary+poetry%22&source=bl&ots=PO7hLRJIHc&sig=2QL4mkzcdFAda8v1yJXd0WgLGsc&hl=en&ei=pe5lSpzfDpK6NY2P0aYB&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8 109] In 1870, [[Mark Twain]] wrote an essay on "Post-mortem Poetry",[[Mark Twain]], [[s:Post-mortem Poetry|Post-mortem Poetry]] in which he remarked that: :In Philadelphia they have a custom which it would be pleasant to see adopted throughout the land. It is that of appending to published death-notices a little verse or two of comforting poetry. Any one who is in the habit of reading the daily Philadelphia LEDGER must frequently be touched by these plaintive tributes to extinguished worth. In Philadelphia, the departure of a child is a circumstance which is not more surely followed by a burial than by the accustomed solacing poesy in the PUBLIC LEDGER. In that city death loses half its terror because the knowledge of its presence comes thus disguised in the sweet drapery of verse. and collected examples, such as the following, occasioned by the death of Samuel Pervil Worthington Doble, aged 4 days. :''Our little Sammy's gone,
His tiny spirit's fled;
Our little boy we loved so dear
Lies sleeping with the dead.'' :''A tear within a father's eye,
A mother's aching heart,
Can only tell the agony
How hard it is to part.'' ==The obituary poets== The deaths of children and young adults were particular objects of inspiration to the obituary poets, who memorialized them with sentimental verse. [[Julia A. Moore]], a [[poet]] from Michigan who published several volumes of poems mostly on obituary subjects, was a well known exponent of the genre. [[George William Childs|G. Washington Childs]],"G. Washington Childs" is believed to be a nickname bestowed on [[George William Childs]], editor in chief of the ''Philadelphia Ledger''. See [[H. P. Blavatsky]], ''The Letters of H. P. Blavatsky'', John Algeo, ed., (Quest, 2003 {{ISBN|0-8356-0836-0}}), vol.1, p. 183 sometimes called "The [[poet laureate|Laureate]] of Grief", was another well known exponent; he was one of the chief authors of the verse appearing in the ''[[Philadelphia Public Ledger]]'' that was noticed by Twain."[http://cbsrfs.ucr.edu/batches/LSTA_20071030.00_flycatcher/sn84031933/00000000112/1875112801/0121.pdf The Laureate of Grief]", [[Daily Alta California]], Nov. 28, 1875, p. 5 [[Lydia Sigourney]],"Mrs Sigourney", in ''The New Englander'', v 25, p. [https://books.google.com/books?id=YfYaAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA338&dq=%22obituary+poet%22&lr= 338] while not confining her work to the genre, frequently contributed to it:[[Lydia Sigourney]], ''[[s:Go To Thy Rest|Go To Thy Rest]]'' ''Ere sin has seared the breast,'' ''Or sorrow waked the tear,'' ''Rise to thy throne of changeless rest,'' ''In yon celestial sphere!'' ==Parodies== Twain's character of "Emmeline Grangerford", appearing in ''[[The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn]]'', was inspired by the genre, and in large measure by Moore's verse.Blair, above Twain's was by no means the only [[parody]] the genre inspired. [[Charles Heber Clark|Max Adeler]] mocked the obituary poets in his 1874 ''Out of the Hurly Burly'', and [[Eugene Field]] produced ''The Little Peach'':[[Eugene Field]], ''[http://www.bartleby.com/102/227.html The Little Peach] :''John took a bite and Sue a chew,
And then the trouble began to brew,—
Trouble the doctor could n't subdue.
— Too true!'' :''Under the turf where the daisies grew
They planted John and his sister Sue,
And their little souls to the angels flew,—
— Boo hoo!'' The obituary poets were, in the popular stereotype, either women or clergymen.[[Ann Douglas (academic)|Ann Douglas]], ''[[The Feminization of American Culture]]'' (Macmillan, 1998, {{ISBN|0-374-52558-7}}), ch. 6, "The Domestication of Death" Obituary poetry may be the source of some of the [[murder ballad]]s and other traditional [[narrative verse]] of the United States, and the sentimental tales told by the obituary poets showed their abiding vitality a hundred years later in the genre of [[teenage tragedy song]]s.[[Robert D. Bethke]], "Narrative Obituary Verse and Native American Balladry", in ''The Journal of American Folklore'', Vol. 83, No. 327 (Jan. - Mar., 1970), pp. 61-68 ==See also== *[[Death poem]] *[[Dirge]] *[[Elegy]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Death customs]] [[Category:Genres of poetry]] [[Category:Victorian poetry]]

{{Infobox book | name = Phantoms | image = Phantoms cover Dean Koontz.jpg | caption = First edition | author = [[Dean Koontz]] | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = [[Thriller (genre)|Thriller]], [[Mystery novel|mystery]], [[Horror (genre)|Horror]] | publisher = [[G. P. Putnam's Sons|Putnam]] | release_date = March 1983 | media_type = Print ([[Hardcover]], [[Paperback]]) | pages = 352 | isbn = 0-399-12655-4 | congress = CPB Box no. 1919 vol. 16 | oclc = 48925027 | preceded_by =<!-- Preceding novel in series --> | followed_by =<!-- Following novel in series --> }} '''''Phantoms''''' is a novel by American writer [[Dean Koontz]], first published in 1983. The story is a version<ref>[http://www.paranormalpeopleonline.com/the-angikuni-mystery-the-case-of-the-missing-village/ The Angikuni Mystery: The Case of the Missing Village] (20 May 2013) Paranormal People.</ref><ref>[http://www.bubblews.com/news/1650951-what-happened-at-the-anjikuni-village-back-in-1930 What happened at the Anjikuni village, back in 1930?] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140226213947/http://www.bubblews.com/news/1650951-what-happened-at-the-anjikuni-village-back-in-1930 |date=2014-02-26 }} (November 24th, 2013) BubbleWS</ref> of the now-debunked<ref>{{Skeptoid|id=4371|number=371|date=16 July 2013|title=The Vanishing Village of Angikuni Lake|accessdate=22 June 2017}}</ref> [[urban legend]]<ref>[http://www.rcmp-grc.gc.ca/hist/anjikuni-eng.htm Royal Canadian Mounted Police Historical Notes]</ref> involving a [[Angikuni Lake#Myth of the vanishing village|village mysteriously vanishing]] at [[Angikuni Lake]].
The novel includes many literary tips of the hat to the work of [[H.P. Lovecraft]], including the suggestion that the novel's 'Ancient Enemy' is Lovecraft's god [[Nyarlathotep]], also known as the 'Crawling Chaos'; and the fact that character of the air force specialist in potential contact with non-human intelligence is named 'Captain Arkham' (cf. Lovecraft's invention [[Arkham]]). <ref> Charles P. Mitchell, ''The Complete H. P. Lovecraft Filmography''. Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 20001, pp. 167-68. </ref>. Most of these Lovecraftian references were excised from the 1998 film version of Koontz's novel.
==Plot summary== Jenny and Lisa Paige, two sisters, return to Jenny's hometown of Snowfield, California, a small ski resort village nestled in the Sierra-Nevada Mountains where Jenny works as a doctor, and find no one alive. The few bodies they find are either mutilated, or reveal some strange form of death. Finally, after growing more alarmed by the town's mysterious and alarming situation Jenny manages to call police in a neighboring town to come help.
Together, the girls and the police, led by Sheriff Bryce Hammond, are able to request help from the military Biological Investigations Unit. The police managed to find only one clue as to what was causing the town's disappearances and deaths. A victim of whatever was trying to kill him managed to write the name Timothy Flyte on a mirror moments before he was killed. Flyte is a [[United Kingdom|British]] academic and author of a book, ''The Ancient Enemy''. His book catalogs and describes various mass vanishings of people in different parts of the world over the centuries.
It is discovered that the town was built over the hibernating place of one such Enemy, a creature known as an [[amoeboid]] [[shapeshifter]]. This Ancient Enemy rarely feeds, but when it does, the effects are devastating. It was theorized that the Enemy either caused or aided in the extinction of the dinosaurs, as well as many of the great mysterious mass vanishings: [[Mayan civilization]], [[Roanoke Colony|Roanoke]], ghost ships, etc.
The creature consumes other life forms to increase its mass and is able to perfectly mimic other creatures. It can create small "probes" or "phantoms" imitating consumed life forms to go forth and hunt more prey, obeying the orders of its "hive mind"; in addition the creature absorbs the mental capacity of those it consumes.
Its only vital organ is a nucleus located in the center of its main body. The creature's cells are similar in molecular structure to [[fossil fuels]]; upon discovering this the scientists use oil-eating bacteria to destroy the Enemy's core or brain. (The genetically modified bacteria are the real-life creations of [[Diamond v. Chakrabarty|Ananda Mohan Chakrabarty]].)
==Court case== In 1992, Koontz filed suit against Zebra Books for the misappropriation of ''Phantoms'' in two titles Zebra published by author "Pauline Dunn" (in actuality sisters Dawn Pauline Dunn and Susan Hartzell collaborating under a pen name). Spotted by a reader who informed Koontz's publisher, the two books in question - ''The Crawling Dark'' and ''Demonic Color'' - mimicked ''Phantoms'' extensively and even copied passages word-for-word. The legal team for Koontz won, resulting in the sisters returning their advances for both books and Zebra placing an ad in ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' acknowledging the plagiarism and withdrawing both titles.<ref>[http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1992-06-26/news/9206260446_1_dean-koontz-dean-r-phantoms Recycling Is Out Of Bounds This Time]</ref>
==Film adaptation== {{main article|Phantoms (film)}}
''Phantoms'' was adapted into [[Phantoms (film)|a movie]] in 1998 starring [[Peter O'Toole]], [[Rose McGowan]], [[Liev Schreiber]], [[Ben Affleck]], and [[Joanna Going]]. It was directed by [[Joe Chappelle]], produced by [[Neo Art & Logic]], and released by [[Dimension Films]]. It was filmed in [[Colorado]].
The film is referenced heavily in ''[[Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back]]'', including once by Affleck himself.
