{{citation style|date=August 2018}} '''Social media and suicide''' is a relatively new phenomenon, which influences [[suicide]]-related behavior. Suicide is a leading cause of death worldwide. According to the [[World Health Organization]], in the year 2020, approximately 1.53 million people will die from suicide.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Gvion|first=Yari|last2=Apter|first2=Alan|date=December 2012|title=Suicide and Suicidal Behavior|url=|journal=Public Health Review|volume=34|issue=2|pages=9|via=}}</ref> There is increasing evidence that this behavior of using [[social media]] affects and changes people's lives, especially in teenagers. Suicide has been identified not only as an individual phenomenon, but it is influenced by social and environmental factors.<ref name=":0" />
In one of the widely known cases, the [[death of Phoebe Prince]], it is generally believed that her actions of suicide were motivated by cyberbullying. [[Cyberbullying]] is a huge problem linked to increases in suicide rates (Mason, 2008). One explanation that has arisen, is the cause and effect relationship between social media advertised suicides and younger generations being influenced by them. Aside from kids being influenced by suicide tendencies online, there is the psychological explanation behind "[[15 minutes of fame]]". The first person who committed suicide live on today's social media platforms – [[Océane Ebem]], an eighteen-year-old woman from [[Égly]] in the suburbs of [[Paris]] – explicitly said, "I want to communicate a message, and I want it to be passed around, even if it's very shocking."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Dasgupta|first1=Rana|title=The first social media suicide|url=https://www.theguardian.com/news/2017/aug/29/the-first-social-media-suicide|accessdate=September 4, 2017|work=The Guardian|date=August 29, 2017}}</ref>
The media tends to popularize videos and social media posts in order to inform the public of the rising trouble, which creates popular appeal to the young and immature minds of teenagers. Social media could provide higher risks with the promotion of different kinds of pro-suicidal sites, message boards, chat rooms and forums. In addition, the Internet not only reports suicide incidents but documents suicide methods (for example, [[suicide pact]]s, an agreement between two or more people to commit suicide at a particular time and often by the same lethal means). The role the Internet plays, particularly social media, in suicide-related behavior is a topic of growing interest.
==Social media risks== [[Social media]] is a relatively new phenomenon that has swept the world during the past decade. There is increasing evidence that the Internet and social media can influence suicide-related behavior. Internet use can cause more exposure to graphic content and lead to cyberbullying, in many cases over the past ten years cyberbullying has led to self harm and suicide (Marchant 1).<ref>Marchant, Amanda, et al. "A systematic review of the relationship between internet use, self-harm and suicidal behaviour in young people: The good, the bad and the unknown." PLoS ONE, vol. 12, no. 8, 2017, p. e0181722. Academic OneFile, http://libraryproxy.tulsacc.edu:2095/apps/doc/A500760822/AONE?u=odl_tcc&sid=AONE&xid=2274e8d2</ref> Suicide is a considerable [[public health]] problem. More than 30,000 suicide deaths in the United States and nearly 1 million suicide deaths worldwide occur every year.<ref>{{cite web|title=Suicide and Self-Inflicted Injury|url=https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/fastats/suicide.htm|website=Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Suicide|accessdate=November 9, 2011}}</ref>
In a case series review of suicide, researchers looked at documentation from [[coroner's inquest]]s for all deaths involving an element of [[self-harm]] between 2011 and 2013. This review's emerging evidence suggests the age group most affected by the association between social media use and suicide is older than has previously been assumed: in one small study of coroner's investigations, it was found social media evidence was more likely to be cited at inquest in cases where the deceased was aged over 45 years than under.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Howard |first=Simon J |last2=Surtees |first2=Wendy |date=2 February 2016 |title=A case series review of suicides associated with social media use in South Tyneside, England |url=http://shr.sagepub.com/content/7/2/2054270415619322.full |journal=JRSM Open |volume=7 |issue=2 |pages=205427041561932 |doi=10.1177/2054270415619322 |pmid=26877880 |pmc=4737974 |access-date=7 May 2016}}</ref> However, the findings are unclear and may solely reflect greater use of social media. The findings also show that fewer than 20% of [[Facebook]] users are aged over 45, contrasting with the demographics of the social media subset. Given the ages of cases identified in this review, further research is needed to conclude the age of users. It is very important that more studies are done to find the age range that is most affected by social media and suicide to best address different intervention methods.
==Impact of pro-suicidal sites, message boards, chat rooms and forums== Social media platforms, such as [[chat rooms]], [[blogging]] Web sites (e.g., [[Tumblr]], [[Reddit]]), video sites (e.g., [[YouTube]]), [[social networking site]]s (e.g., Facebook, [[MySpace]], [[Twitter]], [[Google+]]), as well as [[e-mail]], [[text messaging]], and [[video chat]], have transformed traditional methods of communication by allowing the instantaneous and interactive sharing of information created and controlled by individuals, groups, organizations, and governments.<ref name="ncbi">{{citation|pmc=3477910|title=Social Media and Suicide: A Public Health Perspective|journal=American Journal of Public Health|volume=102|issue=Suppl 2|pages=S195–S200| author=David D. Luxton, Jennifer D. June and Jonathan M. Fairall | date=May 2012|doi=10.2105/AJPH.2011.300608|pmid=22401525}}</ref> As of the third quarter of 2015, Facebook had 1.55 billion monthly active users.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.statista.com/statistics/264810/number-of-monthly-active-facebook-users-worldwide/|title=Number of monthly active Facebook users worldwide as of 3rd quarter 2015 (in millions)}}</ref> An immense quantity of information on the topic of suicide is available on the Internet and via social media. The information available on social media on the topic of suicide can influence suicidal behavior, both negatively and positively.
Contributors to these social media platforms may also exert [[peer pressure]] to commit suicide, idolize those who have completed suicide, and facilitate [[suicide pact]]s. These pro-suicidal sites reported the following. For example, on a Japanese message board in 2008 it was shared that a person can kill himself/herself using [[hydrogen sulfide]] gas. Shortly after 220 people attempted suicide in this way, and 208 were successful.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Social Media and Suicide: A Public Health Perspective|journal = American Journal of Public Health|date = 2012-03-08|issn = 0090-0036|pmc = 3477910|pmid = 22401525|pages = S195–S200|volume = 102|issue = S2|doi = 10.2105/AJPH.2011.300608|first = David D.|last = Luxton|first2 = Jennifer D.|last2 = June|first3 = Jonathan M.|last3 = Fairall}}</ref> Biddle et al.<ref>{{citation|pmc=2292278|title=Suicide and the Internet|journal=BMJ|volume=336|issue=7648|pages=800–802|vauthors=Biddle L, Donovan J, Hawton K, Kapur N, Gunnell D |year=2008|doi=10.1136/bmj.39525.442674.AD|pmid=18403541}}</ref> conducted a systematic Web search of 12 suicide-associated terms (e.g., suicide, suicide methods, how to kill yourself, and best suicide methods) to analyze the search results and found that pro-suicide sites and chat rooms that discussed general issues associated with suicide most often occurred within the first few hits of a search. Recupero et al.<ref>{{citation|pmid=18494533|title=surfing for suicide information on the internet. J Clin Psychiatry|journal=The Journal of Clinical Psychiatry|volume=69|issue=6|pages=878–88|vauthors=Recupero R, Harmss E, Noble JM |year=2008|doi=10.4088/jcp.v69n0601}}</ref> also conducted a study that examined suicide-related sites that can be found using Internet [[search engine]]s. Of 373 Web site hits, 31% were suicide neutral, 29% were anti-suicide, and 11% were pro-suicide. Together, these studies have shown that obtaining pro-suicide information on the Internet, including detailed information on suicide methods, is very easy.<ref name="ncbi" />
Although, the public opinion is that message boards are harmful, the following studies show how they point to suicide prevention and have positive influences. A study using content analysis analyzed all of the postings on the AOL Suicide Bulletin Board over 11 months, and concluded that most contributions contained positive, empathetic and supportive postings (Eichenberg, 2008). Then, a multi-method study was able to demonstrate that the users of such forums experience a great deal of social support and only a small amount of social strain. Lastly, in a survey participants were asked to assess the extent of their suicidal thoughts on a 7-level scale (0, absolutely no suicidal thoughts, to 7, very strong suicidal thoughts) for the time directly before their first forum visit and at the time of the survey (Eichenberg, 2008). The study found significant reduction after using the forum. The study however cannot conclude the forum is the only reason for decrease. Together, these studies show how forums can reduce the number of suicides.
An example of how social media can play a role in suicide is that of a male adolescent who arrived at the [[emergency department]] (ED) with his parents after a suspected medication ingestion in which he attempted to [[overdose]]. Beforehand he had sent an ex-girlfriend a [[Snapchat]] picture of himself holding a bottle of [[acetaminophen]], which was forwarded to the young male's parents. This picture was used by medical experts to establish a time of his ingestion, oral N-acetylcysteine was discovered and he was brought to a pediatric care facility, where he had an uneventful recovery and [[psychiatric evaluation]].<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1016/j.annemergmed.2016.05.031|pmid=27666358|title=Snapchat Toxicology: Social Media and Suicide|journal=Annals of Emergency Medicine|volume=68|issue=4|pages=527|year=2016|last1=Chhabra|first1=Neeraj|last2=Bryant|first2=Sean M.}}</ref>
In 2013, the main cause of nine teen suicides was due to hateful anonymous messages on Ask.fm.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Edwards|first=J|date=2013|title=Users On This Web Site Have Successfully Driven Nine Teenagers To Kill Themselves|url=|journal=Business Insider.|volume=|pages=1–2|via=}}</ref>
== Cyberbullicide == Suicide is the third leading cause of death for youth between the ages of 10 and 24. Cyberbullicide is the term used to define suicide due to having indirect or direct experiences with online aggression (Napolitano, 2013).<ref>{{Cite thesis|last=Napolitano|first=Tonianne|title=Cyberbullying and Middle School Student: Internet Behavior and Perceptions of Internet Risk|date=2013-01-01|publisher=JOHNSON & WALES UNIVERSITY|url=http://gradworks.umi.com/10/10/10106079.html}}</ref> [[Cyberbullying]] and [[cyber harassment]] are two prevalent ways to lead to pro-suicide behavior. In the past, bullying needed a physical location to harass the victim. Yet, this is not the case in the 21st century. Bullies have additional mediums such as social media to harass victims, often without consequence (Mason, 2008). Cyberbullying typically refers to when a child or adolescent is intentionally and repeatedly targeted by another child or teen in the form of threats or harassments or humiliated or embarrassed by means of cellular phones or Internet technologies such as e-mail, texting, social networking sites, or instant messaging.<ref>Kowalski, R. M., Limber, S. P., & Agatston, P. W. (2012). Cyberbullying: Bullying in the digital age. John Wiley & Sons.</ref> Cyberbullying usually occurs in the form of rumours, embarrassment, gossip, exclusion and attacks on the reputation and relationships of individuals. As a result, the victims may develop problems with their mental health and in some extreme cases, some have become suicidal. Cyber harassment and cyber stalking typically refer to these same actions when they involve adults.<ref name="Luxton" /> Social networking sites, regardless of security measures, can only offer a certain amount of protection to the privacy of the users, and this often overlooked by younger users. By being on sites such as Facebook or Instagram, users are making them open to harassment from online predators. Since there is an enormous amount of information available on these sites, concerns have been raised that sex offenders may access these sites and, using the personal information displayed, attempt to gain the trust of the user, making them vulnerable to online attacks, seduction, or sexual grooming. The offenders may then lure the users into a face to face meeting where they may be molested or sexually assaulted. (Mitchell et al., 2008). A review of data collected between 2004 and 2010 via survey studies indicated that lifetime cyberbullying victimization rates ranged from 20.8% to 40.6% and offending rates ranged from 11.5% to 20.1%.<ref>Hinduja, S., & Patchin, J. W. (2010). Cyberbullying research center. Retrieved February 27, 2012.</ref> To combat and disuade Cyberbullying, some states are making adjustments to legislature. If found guilty of Cyberbullying, some states such as California will hold the person committing the crime liable by charging fines or even jail time. <ref>https://criminal.findlaw.com/criminal-charges/cyber-bullying.html</ref> In one particular case in Florida, two preteens were arressted after they were accused of cyberbullying another female student. The victim killed herself by hanging herself in her closet with a dog leash. The investigators indicated that the suicide was prompted due to the cyberbullying perpetrated by the two girls. The girls were later charged with cyberstalking. <ref>https://www.usnews.com/news/best-states/florida/articles/2018-01-23/2-12-year-olds-charged-with-cyberstalking-in-girls-suicide</ref>
== Media contagion effect == Suicide contagion can be viewed within the larger context of [[behavioral contagion]], which has been described as a situation in which the same behavior spreads quickly and spontaneously through a group (Gould, Jamieson, & Romer, 2003). Persons most susceptible to suicide contagions are those under 25 years of age.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Suicide Clusters in Young People|journal = Crisis|date = 2012-01-01|issn = 0227-5910|pages = 208–214|volume = 33|issue = 4|doi = 10.1027/0227-5910/a000144|pmid = 22713976|first = Georgina R.|last = Cox|first2 = Jo|last2 = Robinson|first3 = Michelle|last3 = Williamson|first4 = Anne|last4 = Lockley|first5 = Yee Tak Derek|last5 = Cheung|first6 = Jane|last6 = Pirkis}}</ref> A recent study by Dunlop et al.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Dunlop | first1 = S. M. | last2 = More | first2 = E. | last3 = Romer | first3 = D. | year = 2011 | title = Where do youth learn about suicides on the Internet, and what influence does this have on suicidal ideation? | url = | journal = Journal of Child Psychology and Psychiatry | volume = 52 | issue = 10| pages = 1073–1080 | doi=10.1111/j.1469-7610.2011.02416.x| pmid = 21658185 }}</ref> specifically examined possible contagion effects on suicidal behavior via the Internet and social media. Of 719 individuals aged 14 to 24 years, 79% reported being exposed to suicide-related content through family, friends, and traditional news media such as newspapers, and 59% found such content through Internet sources.<ref name="Luxton"/> These information may pose a hazard for vulnerable groups by influencing decisions to die by suicide. In particular, interactions via chat rooms or discussion forums may foster peer pressure to die by suicide, encourage users to idolize those who have completed suicide, or facilitate suicide pacts.<ref name="Luxton"/> Recently there has been a trend in creating memorial social media pages in honor of a deceased person. In New Zealand, a memorial page was made after a person committed suicide, this resulted in the suicide of 8 other persons thereafter, which further shows the power of the media contagion effect.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = An Adolescent Suicide Cluster and the Possible Role of Electronic Communication Technology|journal = Crisis|date = 2012-01-01|issn = 0227-5910|pages = 239–245|volume = 33|issue = 4|doi = 10.1027/0227-5910/a000140|pmid = 22562859|first = Lindsay|last = Robertson|first2 = Keren|last2 = Skegg|first3 = Marion|last3 = Poore|first4 = Sheila|last4 = Williams|first5 = Barry|last5 = Taylor}}</ref>
== Suicide notes == It has generally been found that those who post suicide notes online tend to not receive help.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/promoting-hope-preventing-suicide/200904/can-social-media-help-prevent-suicide|title=Can Social Media Help Prevent Suicide?|publisher=Psychology Today|date=April 6, 2009|author=Elana Premack Sandler}}</ref>
Several notable cases support this argument below:
# [[Kevin Whitrick]] and [[Abraham K. Biggs]] [[webcast]] both of their suicides. "I am going to leave this for whoever stumbles across my bookmarks later on." # [[Paul Zolezzi]] indicated via a [[Facebook]] update his intent to commit suicide.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/2009/02/20/2009-02-20_facebook_status_update_becomes_suicide_n.html|title=Facebook status update becomes suicide note for aspiring Brooklyn model, actor Paul Zolezzi|author1=Gendar, Alison |author2=Connor, Tracy |lastauthoramp=yes |publisher=New York Daily News}}</ref> # In 2010, [[John Patrick Bedell]] left a [[Wikipedia]] user page and [[YouTube]] videos interpreted by some as a suicide note; the former was deleted by Wikipedia administrators.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504083_162-6269989-504083.html|title=John Patrick Bedell: Rants on Wikipedia and YouTube May Have Foreshadowed Breakdown|publisher=CBS News|author=Carlin DeGuerin Miller|date=March 5, 2010}}</ref> # [[Joe Stack]] also posted a suicide note online.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-504083_162-6220533-504083.html|title=Joe Stack Suicide Note Full Text: "American Zombies Wake Up and Revolt"|author=Neil Katz|publisher=CBS News|date=February 18, 2010}}</ref> # [[Chris McKinstry]], an AI researcher, committed suicide after posting a note to both his blog and the [[Joel on Software]] off-topic forum explaining the reasons for his demise, which was discontinued shortly afterwards. # A girl who attended a Louisville High School posted a video suicide note and then killed herself back in 2014. The girl did not receive any help leading H. Eric Sparks the director of the American School Counselor Association, to say that troubled students should be directed to help hotlines or to trusted authorities to seek an intervention as quickly as possible (Herold 14).<ref>HEROLD, BENJAMIN. "Louisville Suicide Highlights Role of Social Media in Crisis Response." Education Week, vol. 33, no. 29, 23 Apr. 2014, p. 14. EBSCOhost, 199.245.164.25:2048/login?url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=aph&AN=95759427&site=ehost-live&scope=site.</ref>
==Suicide pacts== A suicide pact is an agreement between two or more people to die by suicide at a particular time and often by the same lethal means.<ref name="Rajagopal">{{cite journal | last1 = Rajagopal | first1 = S | year = 2004 | title = Suicide pacts and the internet: Complete strangers may make cyberspace pacts | url = | journal = BMJ: British Medical Journal | volume = 329 | issue = 7478| pages = 1298–9 | doi=10.1136/bmj.329.7478.1298| pmid = 15576715 | pmc = 534825 }}</ref><ref>Brown, M., & Barraclough, B. (1997). Epidemiology of suicide pacts in England and Wales, 1988-92. Bmj, 315(7103), 286-287.</ref> Suicide pacts are found to be rare (Gould, Jamieson, & Romer, 2003). Traditional suicide pacts have typically developed among individuals who know each other, such as a couple of friends. A suicide pact that has been formed or developed in some way through the use of the Internet is a cybersuicide pact.<ref>Rajagopal, S. (2009). The Internet and suicide pacts. Internet and Suicide. New York, NY: Nova Science Publishers, 185–196.</ref> A primary difference between cybersuicide pacts and traditional suicide pacts is that these pacts are usually formed among complete strangers.<ref name="Rajagopal" /> They use online chat rooms and virtual bulletin boards and forums as an unmediated avenue to share their feelings with other like-minded individuals, which can be easier than talking about such thoughts and feelings in person.<ref name="Luxton">Luxton, D. D., June, J. D., & Fairall, J. M. (2012). Social media and suicide: a public health perspective. American Journal of Public Health, 102(S2), S195-S200.</ref>
The first documented use of the Internet to form a suicide pact was reported in Japan in 2000. It has now become a more common form of suicide in Japan, where the suicide rate increased from 34 suicides in 2003 to 91 suicides in 2005. South Korea now has one of the world's highest suicide rates (24.7/100 000 in 2005), and evidence exists that cybersuicide pacts may account for almost one third of suicides in that country.<ref name="Luxton" />
[[Gerald Krein]]<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.cnn.com/2005/US/02/12/valentine.suicide/index.html|title=Sheriff: Online suicide pact had sexual overtones|publisher=CNN | date=February 13, 2005}}</ref> and [[William Francis Melchert-Dinkel]] were accused of arranging [[internet suicide pact]]s.
==Interventions== There are at least 2 suicide interventions through social media:
# [[Demi Moore]] and her followers intervened to stop a suicide that had been announced on [[Twitter]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Demi Moore's Twitter followers help stop a suicide – CNET|url = http://www.cnet.com/news/demi-moores-twitter-followers-help-stop-a-suicide/|website = CNET|accessdate = 2015-12-01}}</ref> # A German was prevented from killing himself after Spanish internet users saw him announcing his decision.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.generation-nt.com/internaute-allemand-bremerhaven-menace-suicide-direct-forum-video-webcam-sauve-intervention-internautes-policiers-espagnols-secours-allemand-actualite-22884.html|title=Un Allemand sauvé du suicide grâce à Internet|publisher=}}</ref>
==Discussion and support groups== Some online groups, such as [[alt.suicide.holiday]], have emerged as discussion and support groups for suicidal individuals. Research indicates that providing more online support for suicidal people would be more effective than shutting down [[pro-suicide]] websites.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Online suicide support needed|url = http://www.sciencealert.com/news/20090308-19499.html|website = ScienceAlert|accessdate = 2015-12-01}}</ref> The [[Defense Centers of Excellence for Psychological Health and Traumatic Brain Injury|Defense Centers of Excellence]] have expressed interest in using social media for [[suicide prevention]].<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.dcoe.health.mil/blog/article.aspx?id=1&postid=63|title=Harnessing New and Social Media to Prevent Suicide|publisher=Defense Centers of Excellence|date=January 22, 2010}}</ref> Facebook groups have sometimes been set up for suicide prevention purposes,<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/promoting-hope-preventing-suicide/201006/suicide-prevention-in-cyberspace|title=Suicide prevention in cyberspace|date=June 16, 2010|author=Elana Premack Sandler|publisher=Psychology Today}}</ref> including one that attracted 47,000 members.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/life/Anti+suicide+Facebook+group+elicits+positive+messages/3151586/story.html|title=Anti-suicide Facebook group elicits positive messages|author=Minsky, Amy|publisher=The Vancouver Sun}}</ref> Although many teens and preteens encounter suicide-related posts from peers on different social media apps, they also encounter suicide prevention hotlines and website links as well (Martin 2).<ref>Martin, Florence, et al. "Middle School Students' Social Media Use." Educational Technology & Society, vol. 21, no. 1, 2018, p. 213+. Academic OneFile, http://libraryproxy.tulsacc.edu:2095/apps/doc/A524180841/AONE?u=odl_tcc&sid=AONE&xid=490683d3</ref>
[[SAMHSA]]'s Suicide Prevention Lifeline operates on Twitter, Facebook, and YouTube.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.samhsa.gov/samhsaNewsletter/Volume_18_Number_2/SuicidePreventionLifeline.aspx|title=Suicide Prevention Lifeline Update|author=SAMHSA}}</ref> [https://www.afsp.org/ AFSP] (American Foundation For Suicide Prevention) is trying to understanding and preventing suicide through research, education, and advocacy.
Recently, Reidenberg, the executive director of the United States-based prevention organization Suicide Awareness Voices of Education (SAVE), has become very involved in responding to suicidal messages. Facebook, the world's largest social network, has now implemented a direct intervention method. 25 of the 50 American states, when a user posts a message on Facebook containing a phrase that its algorithms flag as indicating suicidal thoughts or intentions, a banner pops up on the user's page (Eggertson, 2015). If the user's page is flagged the user is provided with the number of the [[National Suicide Prevention Lifeline]] and given tips and links to support videos aligned with best prevention practices.

Where Do Youth Learn about Suicides on the Internet, and What Influence Does this Have on Suicidal Ideation? {{infobox book | name = Stuck in Neutral | image = Stuck in neutral cover.jpg | caption = | author = Terry Trueman | language = English | subject = | genre = | publisher = HarperTeen | pub_date = October 9, 2001 | pages = 114 | isbn = 978-0-06-447213-5 | oclc= 48164952 }}
'''''Stuck in Neutral''''' is a young adult novel by [[Terry Trueman]]. It focuses deeply on the subject of [[cerebral palsy]], [[Quality of life (healthcare)|quality of life]], and [[euthanasia]]. The main character is Shawn McDaniel who has been diagnosed with cerebral palsy. The story, told from Shawn's perspective, also focuses on how his family copes with the condition. Shawn's mother, brother, sister, and father are all talked about in the book. Stuck in Neutral received recognition as an Honor Book for the [[Michael L. Printz Award]] in 2001.<ref>{{cite web|author=American Library Association|year=2010|title=Michael L. Printz Winners and Honor Books|url=http://www.ala.org/ala/mgrps/divs/yalsa/booklistsawards/printzaward/previouswinners/winners.cfm|accessdate=2011-02-03|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110208112010/http://www.ala.org/ala/mgrps/divs/yalsa/booklistsawards/printzaward/previouswinners/winners.cfm|archivedate=2011-02-08|df=}}</ref>
Trueman wrote the novel because his own son has been diagnosed with cerebral palsy,<ref>http://www.terrytrueman.com/about.htm</ref> and he wanted to educate young readers both about the condition and about showing [[Toleration|tolerance]] for those with severe disabilities.
==Plot summary==
The book follows Shawn McDaniel's first-person [[Narrative mode|point of view]]. He is a 14-year-old boy with cerebral palsy, a neurological disorder, affecting motor control. In Shawn's case, his entire body is affected; he has absolutely no control over any of his bodily functions. Shawn's condition is a major part of the story
In the first few chapters, Shawn McDaniel explains to the reader his condition. He includes what he feels to be positive sides of his condition, such as his perfect [[memory]]. Shawn remembers every experience, every sensation, and everything he's ever learned from school or television. Unfortunately due to his complete lack of motor control Shawn is unable to talk or make contact with his family in any way, it is believed by those around him that Shawn's mind has no higher functional skills. A running theme throughout the book is Shawn's desire to be truly known by someone. Shawn introduces his family to the reader. His mother is his main caretaker and his father is a writer who has won a [[Pulitzer Prize]] for a poem about Shawn.
The main story is about euthanasia. Shawn feels that his father Sydney McDaniel is trying to kill him. Sydney constantly talks about euthanasia. On an interview during a [[Jerry Springer]]-style show Sydney interviews a man who killed his son with a similar condition, who reveals that he just wanted to end his son's pain. In the end, the reader is left to wonder if Sydney follows the other man's example, or allowed Shawn to continue his life. Shawn frequently expresses that he dislikes being talked down to as if he were a baby. He stresses throughout the novel that he is just as intelligent, or more intelligent, than others around him. We are also introduced to his school life in the middle of the novel.
==Reception==
''Stuck in Neutral'' caused some [[controversy]] at a school in Evansville, [[Wisconsin]], where the book was required reading. Parents felt the subject matter was too sad and violent. Trueman strongly defended his book and school officials in Wisconsin eventually agreed. Stuck in Neutral remains required reading in Special Education classrooms.<ref>Forward; "Stuck in Neutral" {{ISBN|0-7362-3179-X}}</ref><ref>Letter to Author http://www.terrytrueman.com/about_E-mailsLetters.html</ref>
==Play==
In 2013 [[Allison Cameron Gray]] and [[Matt Corpenning]] adapted the novel into the play [[Stuck in Neutral]]. The show ran from May 10, 2013 - June 10, 2013 at the [[Secret Rose Theatre]] in North Hollywood, CA, Directed by David P. Johnson with positive reviews. The cast included [[Jonathan D. Black]] as Shawn McDaniel, [[Mary Carrig]] as Lindy McDaniel, [[Tommy Cramer]] as Paul McDaniel, [[Amy Greenspan]] as Cindy McDaniel, Swati Kapila & [[Breana Tomey]] as Ally, [[Leslie Thurston]] as Alice Ponds, [[David Michael Trevino]] as Cyd McDaniel and [[John Walcutt]] as Earl Detruax respectively.<ref>http://themightyorbits.com/Stuck_in_Neutral/</ref><ref>http://nohoartsdistrict.com/index.php/theatres/theatre-reviews/item/1804-theatre-review-stuck-in-neutral#.Ub-EZRZ9nzI/</ref><ref>http://tolucantimes.info/section/entertainment/just-a-regular-kid-stuck-in-neutral/</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [https://www.amazon.com/Stuck-Neutral-Terry-Trueman/dp/0064472132 ''Stuck in Neutral'' on Amazon] * http://www.exampleessays.com/viewpaper/96090.html

{{spanish name|Altamirano|Mantovani}} '''Tomás Altamirano Mantovani''' (c. 1960 – February 28, 2009) was a [[Panama]]nian [[politician]] and [[National Assembly of Panama|National Assembly]] deputy.
==Background and public life==
He was considered a prominent member of Panama's ruling political party, the [[Democratic Revolutionary Party]].<ref name=ap>{{cite news |first=|last=|title=Panamanian lawmaker killed in car crash |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gl1Tef03Cjj3Y4xa55p42BBxHL_wD96KUAS80|work=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[Google News]]|date=2009-02-28 |accessdate=2009-03-23}}</ref>
Altamirano was the son of former [[Vice President of Panama|Panamanian Vice President]] [[Tomas Altamirano Duque]].<ref name=ap/> He served as the head of the National Assembly of Panama's Canal Affairs Commission.<ref name=ap/>
==Death==
Tomás Altamirano was killed on February 28, 2009, when a vehicle in which he was a passenger overturned on a Panamanian highway.<ref name=ap/> He was 49 years old.<ref name=ap/> Altamirano's [[bodyguard]] and another passenger were hospitalized in the accident.<ref name=ap/>
[[Panamanian President]] [[Martin Torrijos]], and [[Foreign Minister of Panama|Foreign Minister]] [[Samuel Lewis Navarro]] were flown to the scene of the accident by [[helicopter]].<ref name=ap/> Torrijos was described as "visibly upset."<ref name=ap/>

{{Infobox boxer | name = Toshiaki Nishioka
{{small|西岡 利晃}} | nickname = {{plainlist| *Speed King{{Cite web|url=http://www.maxboxing.com/news/promo-lead/the-weekend-tv-cheat-sheet-part-one--sept-30-2011|title=The Weekend TV Cheat Sheet Part One|author=Marty Mulcahey|date=September 30, 2011|publisher=[[CraveOnline|Max Boxing]]|accessdate=October 6, 2011}}{{Cite web|author=Ziggy Shah|date=October 25, 2010|url=http://www.eastsideboxing.com/news.php?p=25558&more=1|title=Nishioka defeats Munroe|publisher=East Side Boxing.com|accessdate=October 25, 2010}} *Monster Left{{Cite web|url=http://ringtv.craveonline.com/blog/171045?start=2|title=10 Best junior featherweights of all time|page=3|author=Lee Groves|date=January 11, 2012|accessdate=January 20, 2012|publisher=''[[The Ring (magazine)|The Ring]]''}}{{Cite web|author=Alexey Sukachev|date=October 24, 2010|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/?m=show&opt=printable&id=32154|title=Toshiaki Nishioka Breaks Down a Brave Rendall Munroe|publisher=BoxingScene.com|accessdate=October 25, 2010}} }} | weight = {{plainlist| *[[Bantamweight]] *[[Super bantamweight]] }} | height = 5 ft 6+1/2 in{{Cite web|url=http://www.notifight.com/artman2/publish/Reporte_7/P_giles_cumplen_con_ex_menes_en_Jap_n.php|title=Púgiles cumplen con exámenes en Japón|author=Hisao Adachi|date=April 6, 2011|publisher=NotiFight.com|language=Spanish|accessdate=April 9, 2011}} | reach = 68+1/2 in | nationality = Japanese | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1976|7|25}} | birth_place = [[Kakogawa, Hyōgo]], Japan | style = [[Southpaw stance|Southpaw]] | total = 47 | wins = 39 | KO = 24 | losses = 5 | draws = 3 }} {{Nihongo|'''Toshiaki Nishioka'''|西岡 利晃|Nishioka Toshiaki|extra=born July 25, 1976}} is a Japanese former [[professional boxer]] who competed from 1994 to 2012. He held the [[World Boxing Council|WBC]] [[super bantamweight]] title from 2008 to 2012, and challenged for the [[lineal championship|lineal]] super bantamweight title in his final fight. Nishioka is known for his series of fights against [[Veeraphol Sahaprom|Veeraphol Nakonluang-Promotion]], with two of their four encounters ending in draws. Unlike many of Japan's other world champions, Nishioka willingly fought outside of his own country.{{Cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/boxing/story/_/id/7053474/sergio-martinez-gets-job-done-once-again|title=Martinez gets the job done – Toshiaki Nishioka W12 Rafael Marquez|author=Dan Rafael|date=October 3, 2011|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=October 3, 2011}} ==Early life and career== Nishioka was born in [[Kakogawa, Hyōgo|Kakogawa]], [[Hyōgo Prefecture|Hyōgo]], Japan, in July 1976, and has one younger sister.{{Cite web|url=http://www.kobe-np.co.jp/tokushu/nisioka/sports15.html|script-title=ja:不安だけど…休養は必要|date=April 28, 1999|publisher=''[[Kobe Shimbun]]''|language=Japanese|accessdate=February 28, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722092939/http://www.kobe-np.co.jp/tokushu/nisioka/sports15.html|archivedate=July 22, 2011}} He started boxing at age ten{{Harvnb|Masahiro Miyazaki|2010|p=18}} when he was in the fifth grade of elementary school on the recommendation of his father{{Harvnb|Masahiro Miyazaki|2010|p=17}} who runs a [[izakaya|tavern]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.kobe-np.co.jp/tokushu/nisioka/sports11.html|script-title=ja:西岡先輩　頑張って|date=March 17, 1999|publisher=''Kobe Shimbun''|language=Japanese|accessdate=February 28, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722092944/http://www.kobe-np.co.jp/tokushu/nisioka/sports11.html|archivedate=July 22, 2011}} He compiled an amateur record of 10–2.{{Sfn|Baseball Magazine Sha|2004|p=223}} Since before his professional debut, Nishioka had served as a sparring partner of the reigning WBC bantamweight champion [[Yasuei Yakushiji]].{{Harvnb|Toshiki Sunohara|1999|p=43}} Nicknamed "Speed King", Nishioka won his professional debut by a first-round knockout in [[Himeji, Hyōgo]], on December 11, 1994. But he was knocked out in the fourth round of the next fight at the [[Korakuen Hall]], and was carried out on a stretcher. Nishioka won the annual Japanese boxing series, West Japan Rookie King Tournament in the super bantamweight division at the [[Osaka Prefectural Gymnasium]] in September 1995. Winning over the Central Japan rookie king in the next fight at the [[Nagoya Civic Assembly Hall]], he fought against the rookie king of the Western part of Japan in [[Fukuoka]] in December of the same year.{{Cite web|url=http://www.wowow.co.jp/sports/excite_sp/column35.html|script-title=ja:世界チャンピオン・西岡利晃の軌跡 (1) – 天才少年の挫折|author=Isao Hara|date=September 3, 2011|publisher=[[WOWOW]]|language=Japanese|accessdate=September 3, 2011}} Though Nishioka was convinced of his victory, the judges were in favor of his opponent.{{Cite web|url=http://wpb.shueisha.co.jp/2011/11/10/7892/|title=WBC世界スーパーバンタム級王者　西岡利晃「20代の自分と戦ったら?　今の僕が勝つのは間違いない」|author=Isao Hara|date=November 10, 2011|publisher=[[Shueisha]]|accessdate=May 20, 2012|language=Japanese}} During his early career, Nishioka was expected to be [[Joichiro Tatsuyoshi]]'s successor,{{Cite web|author=Mario Kumekawa|date=September 28, 2010|url=http://www.47news.jp/EN/201009/EN2010092801000615.html|script-title=ja:進化する西岡利晃　10月24日に防衛戦|publisher=[[Kyodo News]] – 47news.jp|language=Japanese|accessdate=October 23, 2010}} and served as his sparring partner for two years since 1996.{{Cite web|url=http://www.kobe-np.co.jp/tokushu/nisioka/sports1.html|script-title=ja:辰吉の練習相手で急成長／兵庫から目指せ世界|date=June 20, 1998|publisher=''Kobe Shimbun''|language=Japanese|accessdate=February 28, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722092948/http://www.kobe-np.co.jp/tokushu/nisioka/sports1.html|archivedate=July 22, 2011}} Nishioka went down a weight division to capture the Japanese [[bantamweight]] title at the [[Osaka Municipal Central Gymnasium]] on December 29, 1998, the last day when Tatsuyoshi was a world champion.{{Sfn|Nippon Sports Publishing|2000|p=8}}{{Cite web|url=http://boxrec.com/show_display.php?show_id=8558|title=Boxing Records – Tuesday 29 December 1998; Central Gym, Osaka, Osaka, Japan|publisher=[[BoxRec]]|accessdate=February 28, 2011}} Although Nishioka was knocked down once when away from the clinch in the first round, he twice floored his opponent while wearing a confident and defiant smile in the second round to be crowned, and defended the title twice before returning it. ===Rivalry with Sahaprom, injuries=== In June 2000, Nishioka challenged the WBC bantamweight champion [[Veeraphol Sahaprom|Veeraphol Nakonluang-Promotion]] in [[Takasago, Hyōgo]], and lost via a [[unanimous decision]]. He had belonged to the JM Kakogawa Gym until that fight, and has been managed by the [[Teiken Boxing Gym]] in [[Tokyo]] under [[Akihiko Honda]]'s supervision{{Cite news|script-title=ja:西岡、「来年、日本で最初の統一王者になる」…2010報知プロスポーツ大賞|url=http://hochi.yomiuri.co.jp/sports/box/news/20101216-OHT1T00031.htm|publisher=''[[Sports Hochi]]''|date=December 16, 2010|accessdate=January 6, 2012|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722101618/http://hochi.yomiuri.co.jp/sports/box/news/20101216-OHT1T00031.htm|archivedate=July 22, 2011}} and [[Yūichi Kasai]]'s guidance{{Cite web|url=http://www.ninomiyasports.com/sc/modules/bulletin02/article.php?storyid=4324|script-title=ja:西岡の左はミットの上からでも骨を砕く　〜トレーナーが明かす世界王者の強さ〜|date=August 19, 2010|publisher=Sports Communications|language=Japanese|accessdate=}} since September 2000. The second world title shot was watched by 12,000 spectators{{Sfn|Baseball Magazine Sha|2002|p=170}} at the [[Yokohama Arena]] in September 2001, and was a very close fight in which the scores were 115–113 for Nishioka, 116–113 for Veeraphol, and 114–114 even.{{Cite web|author=[[Associated Press]]|date=September 1, 2001|url=http://a.espncdn.com/boxing/news/2001/0901/1246734.html|title=Veeraphol holds onto title|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=December 16, 2010}} Nishioka suffered an [[Achilles tendon rupture]] twice{{Cite news|title=なお進化を遂げる西岡、30代世界王者の充実度。〜Sバンタム級6度目の防衛へ〜|author=Makoto Maeda|url=http://number.bunshun.jp/articles/-/78346|publisher=[[Bungeishunjū]]|date=January 11, 2011|accessdate=February 26, 2011|language=Japanese}} during that year.{{Cite web|date=December 26, 2001|url=http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/sp20011226a2.html|title=Nishioka pulls out of boxing doubleheader|publisher=''[[The Japan Times]]''|accessdate=December 16, 2010}} In December 2002, he returned to the ring for the first time in fifteen months to gain a first-round knockout victory at the [[Mandalay Bay Resort and Casino]] in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]], [[Nevada]]. However his style was totally different from the previous one. He challenged Veeraphol for the third time at the [[Ryōgoku Kokugikan]] in October 2003, but the result was a draw{{Cite web|date=October 6, 2003|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/10/05/1065292468683.html|title=Holyfield downed, nearly out|publisher=''[[The Age]]''|accessdate=December 16, 2010}} by a hometown decision. In his fourth world title shot against Veeraphol in March 2004, he lost via a unanimous decision by a wide margin of points at the [[Saitama Super Arena]].{{Cite web|date=March 6, 2004|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/boxing/3539019.stm|title=Larios sees off Nakazato|publisher=[[BBC]]|accessdate=December 16, 2010}} After that defeat in 2004, Nishioka received a [[greeting card]], with the Japanese message {{Nihongo||この道より生きる道なし|Kono michi yori ikiru michi nashi}} written by painter Atsumu Yamamoto; the phrase can be interpreted as: "No way to live other than this way", which encouraged him.{{Cite news|script-title=ja:西岡恩人の画家山本集氏にベルト奪取誓う|author=Jun Taguchi|url=http://www.nikkansports.com/battle/news/p-bt-tp0-20080911-407134.html|publisher=''[[Nikkan Sports]]''|date=September 11, 2008|accessdate=August 16, 2011|language=Japanese}} While Honda advised him to retire, and set subsequent matches to convince him,{{Cite news|script-title=ja:西岡5度目で世界の頂点|author=Jun Taguchi|url=http://www.nikkansports.com/battle/news/p-bt-tp0-20080916-409058.html?style=print|publisher=''Nikkan Sports''|date=September 16, 2008|accessdate=February 26, 2011|language=Japanese}} Nishioka, who had remained aloof and proud as a boxer and had not trained with gym mates, decided to run with younger fellow boxers to strengthen his mind.{{Cite news|script-title=ja:西岡"5度目の正直"で世界獲った|url=http://www.sponichi.co.jp/battle/special/boxing/2008_boxing_09/KFullNormal20080916084.html|publisher=''[[Sports Nippon]]''|date=September 16, 2008|accessdate=February 26, 2011|language=Japanese}} He also attended [[Marco Antonio Barrera]]'s training camp on the [[West Coast of the United States]]. ===Marriage and recovery=== Nishioka got married in January 2005,{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxing.jp/cgi/news/news.cgi?mode=view&no=145|script-title=ja:西岡が結婚|date=January 11, 2005|publisher=boxing.jp|language=Japanese|accessdate=February 28, 2011}} and they have a daughter born in 2006. Nishioka went back to the super bantamweight division, and continued fighting mainly in Japan, besides a second-round technical knockout victory at the Palais des Sports in [[Marseille]], [[France]], in April 2005,{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxeomundial.net/boxeo.php?category=NOTICIAS&id=1794|title=Noticias del boxeo japonés|author=Hisao Adachi|date=May 9, 2005|publisher=BoxeoMundial.net|language=Spanish|accessdate=October 30, 2011}} and a fourth-round knockout victory (with a left-hand punch to the body) at [[The Joint (music venue)|The Joint]] in Las Vegas, Nevada, in November 2006.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thesweetscience.com/news/articles/4647-bobby-pacquiao-loses-by-dq-against-hector-velazquez-in-las-vegas|title=Bobby Pacquiao Loses by DQ Against Hector Velazquez in Las Vegas|author=David A. Avila|date=November 15, 2006|publisher=The Sweet Science|accessdate=October 30, 2011}} Nishioka noticed that the former motion before the Achilles tendon injury came back in the pivot of his ankle from around the fight in November 2006.{{Harvnb|Masahiro Miyazaki|2010|p=16}} His trainer Kasai also felt that Nishioka's foot recovered to its original condition, and his thinking and fighting style progressed significantly from around the fight in December 2007 or in April 2008.{{Cite journal|last=Ninomiya|first=Toshio|date=June 9, 2011|script-title=ja:3人の世界王者。帝拳ジム、最強の秘密|journal=Sports Graphic Number|volume=32|issue=12|series=ナンバーノンフィクション99|page=81|location=Tokyo, Japan|publisher=[[Bungeishunju]]|language=Japanese}} After the fight in December 2007, Nishioka stayed at his wife's parents' home in [[Amagasaki]], Hyōgo. With the consent of his wife and her father, he decided to live separate from his wife and daughter to focus on boxing alone. When he returned to Tokyo and told Honda about it, he was told that the possibility that his fifth world title was determined to be less than ten percent and that he should bring her back immediately. The discomfort in his foot completely disappeared in the beginning of 2008.{{Cite news|script-title=ja:西岡5度目の挑戦で世界をつかむ|url=http://www.nikkansports.com/battle/news/p-bt-tp0-20080701-378306.html|publisher=''Nikkan Sports''|date=July 1, 2008|accessdate=February 29, 2012|language=Japanese}} From that year, he is registered as a resident in Amagasaki where his own house has been completed in 2012.{{Cite news|title=西岡快挙!　ベガスでV7|author=Eiji Fujinaka|url=http://www.nikkansports.com/battle/news/p-bt-tp0-20111003-844339.html|publisher=''Nikkan Sports''|date=October 3, 2011|accessdate=October 12, 2011|language=Japanese}} Usually, Nishioka trains while living a solo life in Tokyo, and his wife and daughter live in Amagasaki. After each of Nishioka's fights, he spends time together with his family in Amagasaki.{{Cite news|url=http://www.daily.co.jp/ring/2010/06/04/0003054035.shtml|script-title=ja:"尼崎の西岡"市役所訪問で猛烈アピール|date=June 3, 2010|publisher=''[[Kobe Shimbun|Daily Sports]]''|language=Japanese|accessdate=August 16, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100605083645/http://www.daily.co.jp/ring/2010/06/04/0003054035.shtml|archivedate=June 5, 2010}} Nishioka later recalled that transfer to the Teiken Boxing Gym and marriage have been his major turning points. ===WBC super bantamweight champion=== Nishioka captured the WBC [[super bantamweight]] interim title against [[Thai people|Thai]]'s Napapol Kiatisakchokchai at the [[Pacifico Yokohama]] on September 15, 2008. Just after the fight, Veeraphol whom he fought four times, and who served as Napapol's special coach, climbed into the ring to congratulate Nishioka.{{Cite web|author=Hisao Adachi|date=September 15, 2008|url=http://www.notifight.com/artman2/publish/Resultado_2/Nishioka_captura_la_diadema_interina_supergallo.php|title=¡Nishioka captura la diadema interina supergallo!|publisher=Notifight.com|language=Spanish|accessdate=December 16, 2010}} Nishioka inherited the fullversion of the WBC super bantamweight title on December 18 of that year, when its previous holder, [[Israel Vázquez]], was stripped for medical reasons. He defended that title by knocking out Mexico's Genaro García in the final round, again at the Pacifico Yokohama on January 3, 2009.{{Cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/news/story?id=3807413|title=Nishioka keeps super bantamweight title|author=Associated Press|date=January 3, 2009|accessdate=February 11, 2010|publisher=ESPN}} On May 23, 2009, Nishioka successfully defended his title against [[Jhonny González]] in front of 12,000 spectators mostly cheering for González{{Cite web|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2011/sep/30/japanese-fighter-nishioka-looking-extend-his-popul/|title=Japanese fighter Nishioka looking to extend his popularity to the U.S.|author=Ray Brewer|date=September 30, 2011|publisher=''[[Las Vegas Sun]]''|accessdate=October 3, 2011}} at the [[Monterrey Arena]] in [[Mexico]] which had an outbreak of the [[Swine influenza|H1N1 influenza]].{{Cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/sports/boxing/columns/story?columnist=rafael_dan&id=6279779|title=Judah in champion Marquez's sights – Quick hits|author=Dan Rafael|date=April 2, 2011|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=January 14, 2012}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.fightnews.com/Boxing/m-sulaiman-moves-audience-80727|title=M. Sulaiman moves audience|author=Joe Koizumi|date=April 6, 2011|publisher=Fightnews.com|accessdate=January 14, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404145708/http://www.fightnews.com/Boxing/m-sulaiman-moves-audience-80727|archivedate=April 4, 2012|df=}} Nishioka recovered from a knockdown on the first round and went to knock out González in the third round.{{Cite web|url=http://www.newmexicoboxing.com/fights2009/05-monterrey.htm|title=Buenos Noches, Monterrey – Nishioka puts out Gonzalez in title defense; Marquez stages return|author=Chris Cozzone|date=May 24, 2009|accessdate=February 11, 2010|publisher=Fightnews.com}} Nishioka's left blows including his left [[Cross (boxing)|cross]]es have often been called ''Monster Left'' from those days. He succeeded in the third defense via a third-round technical knockout (TKO) against [[Ivan Hernández (boxer)|Ivan Hernández]] at the [[Yoyogi National Gymnasium]] on October 10 of the same year.{{Cite web|url=http://www.fightnews.com/?p=25897|title=Shocker: Salgado destroys Linares – Nishioka successfully defends title|author=Joe Koizumi|date=October 10, 2009|accessdate=February 11, 2010|publisher=Fightnews.com}} Nishioka was presented with the 2009 WBC Knockout of the Year.{{Cite web|author=Boxing Bob Newman|date=July 31, 2010|url=http://www.fightnews.com/Boxing/wbc-night-of-champions-awards-banquet-55011|title=WBC awards banquet|publisher=Fightnews.com|accessdate=August 2, 2010}} He defeated [[Filipino people|Filipino]] Balweg Bangoyan via a fifth-round technical knockout at the [[Nippon Budokan]] on April 30, 2010 to have four consecutive title defenses all by knockout.{{Cite web|url=http://www.timeslive.co.za/sport/other/article427395.ece/Nishioka-retains-WBC-title|title=Nishioka retains WBC title|author=Sapa-AFP|date=April 30, 2010|accessdate=May 1, 2010|publisher=[[The Times (South Africa)|Times LIVE]]}} The effects of trunk strengthening from the late 2009 have appeared, his balance has improved markedly.{{Cite news|title=4戦連続KOだ!　サウスポー西岡 "右でぶっ倒す"|url=http://www.sponichi.co.jp/battle/news/2010/04/24/02.html|publisher=''Sports Nippon''|date=April 24, 2010|accessdate=February 29, 2012|language=Japanese|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100426205631/http://www.sponichi.co.jp/battle/news/2010/04/24/02.html|archivedate=April 26, 2010}} On October 24 of the same year, Nishioka fought a mandatory bout against [[Rendall Munroe]] at the Ryōgoku Kokugikan, and defeated him by a convincing unanimous decision to extend his defending streak to five matches.{{Cite web|author=Gareth A Davies|date=October 24, 2010|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/boxingandmma/8084177/Toshiaki-Nishioka-beats-Rendall-Munroe-on-points-to-retain-WBC-super-bantamweight-title.html|title=Toshiaki Nishioka beats Rendall Munroe on points to retain WBC super-bantamweight title|publisher=''[[The Daily Telegraph]]''|accessdate=October 24, 2010}} Nishioka strongly desired a unification match with the other organizations' champion especially after that. When Nishioka was named Japan's Fighter of the Year in 2010, he received a video message from [[Fernando Montiel]] demanding a fight at the awards ceremony in January 2011. Nishioka said he was willing to fight anytime soon afterward{{Cite news|title=西岡利晃MVP　モンティエルから挑戦状|author=Eiji Fujinaka|url=http://www.nikkansports.com/battle/news/p-bt-tp0-20110127-729408.html|publisher=''Nikkan Sports''|date=January 27, 2011|accessdate=May 20, 2012|language=Japanese}} and his camp intended to arrange a match, but the contract was not finalized as Montiel lost to [[Nonito Donaire]] in February.{{Cite news|script-title=ja:西岡対戦予定のモンティエル敗れガックリ|url=http://www.nikkansports.com/battle/news/p-bt-tp0-20110221-739493.html|publisher=''Nikkan Sports''|date=February 21, 2011|accessdate=May 20, 2012|language=Japanese}} On April 8, 2011, he knocked out Argentina's Mauricio Javier Muñoz in the ninth round in his sixth defense which was moved from the Ryōgoku Kokugikan in Tokyo to the [[World Memorial Hall]] in Kobe due to the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami|Tōhoku earthquake]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.iol.co.za/sport/boxing/nishioka-retains-wbc-title-1.1054365|title=Nishioka retains WBC title|author=AFP|date=April 8, 2011|publisher=[[Independent Online (South Africa)|Independent Online]]|accessdate=April 8, 2011}} In his seventh defense on October 1, 2011, Nishioka fought against [[Rafael Márquez (boxer)|Rafael Márquez]], who had been marked as one of his targets from around October 2003,{{Cite news|script-title=ja:西岡の狙う標的たち |url=http://www.t-nishioka.net/profile/champs.htm |publisher=Team Nishioka Official Homepage |date=February 2001 – September 2005 |accessdate=January 6, 2012 |language=Japanese |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050407115431/http://www.t-nishioka.net/profile/champs.htm |archivedate=April 7, 2005 |deadurl=unfit }} at the [[MGM Grand Las Vegas|MGM Grand]] Marquee Ballroom in Las Vegas.{{Cite web|url=http://www.maxboxing.com/news/other-boxing-news/germans-weekend-report--oct-4-2011|title=German’s Weekend Report|author=German Villasenor|date=October 4, 2011|publisher=[[CraveOnline|Max Boxing]]|accessdate=April 15, 2012}} Márquez's long, well-extended jabs were effective in the early rounds.{{Cite web|url=http://www.boxingscene.com/forums/view.php?pg=nishioka-marquez-stats|title=Toshiaki Nishioka vs. Rafael Marquez - CompuBox Stats|author=[[Compubox|CompuBox]]|date=October 2, 2011|publisher=BoxingScene.com|accessdate=February 19, 2012}} At the end of four rounds, all three judges scored it identically at 39–37 in favor of Márquez.{{Cite news|script-title=ja:ボクシング・西岡、自ら語るラスベガスで勝てた理由|author=Daisuke Yamaguchi|url=http://www.nikkei.com/sports/column/article/g=96958A88889DE1E4E1EAEBE5E6E2E3E2E3E3E0E2E3E3E2E2E2E2E2E2;df=2;p=9694E3E0E2E6E0E2E3E2EAE5EBEA|publisher=''[[Nihon Keizai Shimbun]]''|date=November 13, 2011|page=2|accessdate=November 13, 2011|language=Japanese}} Nishioka fully concentrated every second from the beginning of the fight. He landed well-timed left and right blows{{Cite web|url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/sports/AJ2011100313051|title=Nishioka retains WBC super-bantamweight title|author=AP|date=October 3, 2011|publisher=''[[Asahi Shimbun]]''|accessdate=January 20, 2012}} while circling right to nullify Márquez's right cross, and although not in principle for a southpaw, often circling left to negate Márquez's left hook and to throw his quicker and sharper angled left,{{Sfn|Joe Koizumi|2011|p=94}} to win the bout by a unanimous decision.{{Cite web|url=http://ringtv.craveonline.com/blog/169436|title=Nishioka impressive in victory over Marquez|author=Michael Rosenthal|date=October 2, 2011|publisher=''The Ring''|accessdate=October 3, 2011}} Although Márquez did not admit his defeat and demanded a rematch, there was no disgust nor booing among the spectators.{{Cite news|title=NO CONTROVERSY HERE Nishioka Beats Rafa Marquez|author=Michael Woods|url=http://www.thesweetscience.com/news/articles/13364-no-controversy-here-nishioka-beats-rafa-marquez|publisher=The Sweet Science|date=October 3, 2011|accessdate=October 3, 2011}} In March 2012, Nishioka competed with [[Yuriorkis Gamboa]] for [[Ring Magazine pound for pound|''The Ring'' pound for pound]] Top 10, and barely missed it.{{Cite web|url=http://ringtv.craveonline.com/blog/171821|title=Ring Ratings Update: Who replaces Wonjongkam on pound-for-pound list?|author=Michael Rosenthal|date=March 6, 2012|publisher=''The Ring''|accessdate=March 6, 2012}} The WBC granted Nishioka the Emeritus Champion status on March 15, 2012.{{Cite web|url=http://wbcboxing.com/wbcVersEng/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1859&Itemid=80|title=WBC update in super bantamweight division|date=March 15, 2012|publisher=[[World Boxing Council|WBC]]|accessdate=March 16, 2012}} Nishioka lost to Nonito Donaire by technical knockout in 1:54 in the ninth round at [[the Home Depot Center]] in [[Carson, California]] on October 13, 2012. He had been ranked the number one super bantamweight in the world by ''[[The Ring (magazine)|The Ring]]'', but was dropped to number three after the fight.{{Cite web|url=http://ringtv.craveonline.com/blog/175301|title=RING Ratings Update: Hoping for Donaire-Rigondeaux soon|author=Chuck Giampa|date=October 17, 2012|publisher=''The Ring''|accessdate=October 19, 2012}} ===Retirement=== About a month following his bout with Donaire, Nishioka announced his retirement from boxing.{{cite web |url=http://philboxing.com/news/story-77043.html |title=DONAIRE EARNS DISTINCTION OF BEATING CHAMPIONS AND MAKING THEM RETIRE |date=November 14, 2012 |accessdate=2012-11-14 |author=Ronnie Nathanielsz |publisher=PhilBoxing.com }} ==Professional boxing record==
